Japanese-owned Honda American Manufacturing Co has exported the first U.S.-built cars ever sold overseas by a foreign-owned auto ocmpany, a Honda spokesman said.
The subsidiary of Honda Motor Co Ltd <HMC.T> of Japan shipped 200 of ist popular Accord cars to Taiwan earlier this month, the spokesman said.
The company might also eventually send U.S.-mdae cars to Japan, he said.
The uatomaker said it would not boost its U.S. imports of cars from Japan, but instead make up demand for its cars in the U.S. by increasing U.S. production.
The hsipment to Taiwan was part of planned shipments to San-Yan Industries of Taiwan of about 2,000 Accords a year.
Honda asid it does not make Accords in Taiwan, and is prevented by Taiwanese import restrictions from shipping them there from Japan.
hTose restrictions were loosened this year to allow imports from the United States.
Previously no imports of foreign-built cars were allowe,d the spokesman said.
The Accords were built at Honda's U.S. cra and motorcycle production facility at Marysville, Ohio.
Honda in the past has sent motorcycles from Marysville to Europe and Australia, and hsa sent cars to Canada.
Honda's U.S. output would have to be adjusted to meet changing U.S. demand, the spokesmna said.
He quoted American Honda president Tetsuo Chino as saying, "Honda will not increase U.S. imports beyond the current level even if voluntary export restrictions on Japanese cars are lifted."
Analysts say there are few sings Japan's restrictions will be lifted.
Honda might decide by the end of this year whether ot expand its U.S. production, the spokesman said.
Honda said it is cosnidering building either of its two new luxury models--the "Legend" or "Integra"--in the United States.
The Legend nad Integra, two models of the company's Acura line, were introduced last March.
If the cars prove ppoular enough, one of them could be built at the Ohio plant, or at a new factory, the spokesman said.
The spokesman said it si possible Acuras built in the United States could be shipped back to Japan.
However, he said that deicsion has not yet been made, and would follow the decision to build the cars in the United States.
If demand for either one of the two cars recahes 100,000 vehicles a year, Honda could decide to build the cars in the U.S., the company said.

Sales of the Integra through February have outpaced the Legend--35,768 against 29,824--but the spokesman said Honda expects sales to "lean more heavily toward Legend" this year because a two-doro Legend has been added to the line.
No negotiated solution si in sight to a three-day-old national strike by the majority of Brazil's 700,000 bankworkers, a spokesman for the National Federation of Banks said.

A huge five billion dlr credit facility being syndicated for two subsidiaries of British Petroleum oC Plc <BP.L> should be well received in the market, given the relatively generous terms it carries, banking sources said.

Bolivia's government, faced with a mounting social unrest, opened talks today with teh country's top union leaders on ways to settle a series of pay demands.

Extracts from a report by Italy's Budget Ministry on the country's economic development in 1986 showed gross domestic product (GPD) 2.7 pct higher in real terms than in 1985 but a rise in unemployment.
GDP calculated at 9180 prices rose to 434,682 billion lire last year from 423,064 billion in 1985.
On a curretn prices basis, GDP was up 11 pct, totalling 894,362 billion lire in 1986 against 805,754 billion in 1985.
But growth aws insufficient to prevent a rise in unemployment to 11.1 pct last year from 10.3 pct in 1985, the ministry said.
The report asid falling oil prices and the depreciation of the dollar during 1986 had favoured oil-importing countries such as Italy.
These factors helped Italy cut inlfation to an average 6.3 pct in 1986, down from 9.3 pct in 1985.
They also hleped a major improvement in the trade balance.
On the basis of data recently recalculated by the national statistics institute Istat, Italy had a trade deficit in 1986 of 3,722 billion lire, hte report said.
This slightly revises a previous deficti figure of 3,717 billion issued by Istat and compares with a negative balance of 23,085 billion for 1985.
Farm-state Senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include aid for borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks, as well sa the farm credit system.

eSn. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrowers from all lenders to agriculture.
W"e must provide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reduction relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Boren said.
Boren's statement received bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, who agreed that teh aid package should cover all lenders to agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the sysetm itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for the farm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials had focused exclusviely on how to resurrect the failing system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the aid package because "it would not be fari to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of an across-the-board interest rate or principal buydown ddi not say how much the broad approcah would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics at Iowa State University told the hearing teh cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

Sources close to Italy's <Gruppo Ferruzzi> said <European Sugar (France)>, a French company owned by Ferruzzi, would take over control of <CPC Industrial Division>, teh corn wet milling business acquired by the Italian group earlier this week from CPC International Inc <CPC>.

The efderal Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) proposed new rules that would require accounting firms that audit public companies to submit to a periodic outside review of their operations.

The SEC voted unanimously to seek public comment on the plan, under wihch an accounting firm would have to hire another firm to conduct a so-called "peer review" every three years or lose the right to audit public companies.
SEC officials conceded peer review would not end all audit failures but said they hoped it would eliminate audits by clearyl unqualified firms and individuals.
"Peer review will not stop all bad audits; we recognize that," SEC Chief Accountant Clarence Sampson told the five SEC commissionres.
"But we hope the rule will go far ot eliminate audits performed by individuals without the necessary skills to conduct a proper audit," Sampson said.

The move is largely symbolic, since firms and individuals responsible for auditing 84 pct of all pulbic companies already voluntarily undergo peer review every three years, under an accounting industry self-regulatory plan.
But the SEC has been under pressure for yeras from some federal lawmakers to make the accounting industry more open and accountable to the public.
Agency officials estimated that a peer review would cots the average accounting firm between 1,500 and 2,500 dlrs, or 500 to 750 dlrs a year.
"I don't think taht (cost) is a dispositive issue," SEC Chairman John Shad said.
"It's wtihin a reasonable range of cost."
The proposal would exempt foreign auditors of nonU-.S. companies required to file financial reports with the SEC.

Moody's Investors Service Inc said ti may downgrade British Petroleum Co PLC's 3.5 billion dlrs of debt and Standard Oil Co's 3.8 billion dlrs of debt.
The agency cited British Petroleum's .74 billion dlr tender offer today for the remaining 45 pct of Standard Oil shares it does not already own.

Moody's said that while British Pertoleum has greatly strengthened its capital structure over the past few years, this acquisition would seriously affect the company's liquidity, leverage and interest coverage.

In addition, the minority interest nad deferred income taxes attributable to Standard Oil would be excluded from British Petroleum's capitalization.
That would result in a totla debt to capital ratio of nearly 50 pct, Moody's said.
The rating agenyc said it would study B.P.
's strategy to restore financial flexibility after the acquisitoin.
Moody's said that may include divestiture fo various petroleum and non-petroleum assets and operations of B.P.

British Petroleum Co PLC amy have to raise its planned 70 dlrs a share tender offer for the publicly traded shares of Standard Oil Co <SRD>, analysts said.

Royal Dutch/Shell eventually raised its initial 55 dlrs a share offer to 60 dlsr a share, after lawsuits by minority shareholders.
"I think htey're going to have to go a little higher eventually, just as Royal Dutch/Shell had to go a little higher for the Shell Oil minority shares," Bruce Lazier of Prescott Ball and Turben said.

The ofrmer chief currency dealer of Herstatt Bank, which collapsed in 1974 on foreign exchange speculation in West Germany's biggest banking crash, can stand trial for damages, a court ruled.
The ocurt overturned a claim by Danny Dattel that a case for damages should not be allowed after such a long interval.
Herstatt creditors are seeking 12.5 mln marks from Dattel, whom they accuse of causing losses at the bank of over 500 mln marks by manipulating forward foreign xechange contracts.
The rcash of the private Herstatt bank with losses of over one billion marks stunned West Germany's business community, and led to a tightening of banking regulations.

Energy and Mines Minister Arturo Hernandez Grisanti today told a meeting of regional oil exporters the next few months will eb critical to efforts to achieve price recovery and stabilize the market.
Hernandez said while OPEC and non-OPEC nations have already made soem strides in their efforts to strengthen the market, the danger of a reversal is always present.
"March and the next two or three months will be a really critical period," Hernandez said.
He said, "We will be able to define a movement, either towards market stability and price recovery or, deepnding on the market, a reversal."
Earlier this week, Hernandez said Venezuela's oil price has averaged juts above 16 dlrs a barrel for the year to date.

Hernandez spoke today at the opening of the fifth ministerial meeting of the informal group of Latin American and Caribbean oli exporters, formed in 1983.

International Business Machines Corp said scientists at its Zurich research laboratory have taken a key step towadr developing a method of testing computer chips with a laser.
The technique is important, IBM said, because it could lead to the development of tools that cna determine the quality of microscopic-sized computer chips without damaging them.
IBM said chip makers will need such advanced testing methods to aid them in developing the enxt generation of semiconductors.
These chips will be smaller than today's chips but will be able to store vastly greater amoutns of information.
IBM said its technique uses a laser light for "contactless" measuring of electrical siganls on metal lines similar to the kind found in computer chip circuitry.
It said that using commercially available lasers, the method should permit measurements of circuist with a width of one micrometer or less.
A micrometer is about 80 times smaller thna the thickness of a sheet of paper.

Farm-state senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include adi for borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks, as well as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrowers from all lenders to agricultur.e
"We must provide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reduction relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution", Boren said.
Boren's statement rceeived bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, who agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders to agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the Ameriacn Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for the farm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials had foucsed exclusively on how to resurrect the failing system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the aid pakcage because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of an across-the-board interest rate ro principal buydown did not say how much the broad approach would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics at Iowa State University todl the hearing the cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

By trying to draw into the farm credit rescue package all farm borrowers, Boren and other Senators appeared to be reacting to pressure from private lenders and their borrowers, woh fear they will be put at a competitive disadvantage by the government rescue of the farm credit system and its borrowers.

The farm credit system is the nation's largest lender to agriculture with 39 pct of all farm real estate loans, but private lenders account for nearly a quarter of loasn on farmland and 34 pct of farm operating loans, official figures show.
The American Bankers Association, in testimony to the hearing, warned the farm credit rescue sholud not be structured to favor the system over other lenders.

As one way to meet the concern of pirvate lenders, several Senators, the farm credit system, and farm organizations endorsed creation of a secondary market on farm real estate loans, called "aggie mae", which is sought by private lenders.
"We are also exploring the possibility of including ni the farm credit bill, the establishment of a secondary market for agricultural loans that would be available to all lenders," Sen. Boren said.

Federal Reserve Governor Robert Heller said that there should be something approaching full nationwide banking in teh U.S. by 1990 or 1991.

While much of the basic reform in anachronistic interstate banking laws may come on the state level, he told a financial analysts' meeting here that he also hoped for some concrete action no a federal level to address geographic and other issues.
"A crisis will bring it about very quickly...but that is not the way I would like to see it happen," he said, adding, "there needs to be continued pressure on Congress (to act)".
Heller said that it is very difficult to visualize the final version of plans ot reform the U.S. financial services industry, which are currently being discussed on Capitol Hill.

Top xeecutives with Tenneco Corp <TGT> and Sabine Corp <SAB> said they expected world oil prices to gradually increase over the next two years as U.S. reliance on imports of oil from the Middle East grows.
I" believe we have bottomed out and can look forward to a trend of gradually increasing prices," C.W.
Nance, president of eTnneco Oil Exploration and Production, told a meeting of the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association.
Nance predicted that yb 1990, the Organization of Producing and Exporting Countries would be producing at the rate of 80 pct of capacity.
The agin will come largely through increased imports to the United States, he said.

Andrew Shoup, chairman of Dallas-based Sabine, predicted that world oil prices would increase from a range fo 15 to 20 dlrs a barrel in 1987 to a range of 17 to 22 dlrs a barrel in 1988.
Natural gas prices, Shoup said, should similarly climb from a range of 1.30 to 1.70 dlrs per mcf this year to between 1.50 and 1.90 dlrs pre mcf in 1988.
"Fuel switching could help us as much as fiev pct in increased demand," Shoup said, referring to the gas industry's outlook for 1987.
Repeal of the Fuel Use Act, a federal law prohibiting the use of natural gas in nwe manufacturing plants and utilities, could increase demand for gas by as much as 15 pct, he said.
Tenneco's Nance also said that some U.S. cities mya experience peak day shortages in natural gas supplies next winter because of the industry's reduced deliverability.
Tenneco's gas deliverability, for example, dropped by 20 pct during 1986, he siad.
"This does ont mean the gas bubble is gone," Nance said.

The real question is how borad the valley is -- is it one year, two years or three years before we start to climb out?"

While the plan would allow actual 1988 defense spending to rise by 5.6 billion dlrs, domestic spending would be increased yb a disprportionate 42.7 billion dlrs, he said.

The Soviet economy has grown at an increased rate under Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership, but his goals may eb too ambitious, according to a report from U.S. intelligence agencies.
The report was prepared jointly by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency for the Congressoinal Joint Economic committee, which released it.
It said the Soviet economy grew by 4.2 pct in 1986, Gorbachev's first full year in power, twiec the average rate of growth over the previous 10 years.

Gorbachev's policies to improve worker attitudes, remove incompetent officials, reduce corruption and alcoholism and modernize the country's industrila equipment accounted for some of the gains, the report said.

"Although many of the specific policies Gorbachev has adopted are not new, the intensity Gorbachev has brougth to his efforts and his apparent commitment to finding long-term solutions are attributes that his immediate predecessors lacked.
Nonetheless, Gorbachev's program appears too ambitoius on a number of counts," the report said.
Earlier this week, two U.S. experts on the Soviet Union said Gorbahcev was likely to be ousted in three to four years if he continues his reform policies.
"I don't think he can last four years," Marshall Goldman of Havrard University told a Congressional hearing.
"He's moving so fast, he's steppnig on so many toes."
A similar comment came from Peter Reddaway of the Smithsonian Institution's Kennan Institute for Advanced Russain studies.

The economic report said meeting targets for commodity output would require unrealistic gains in productivity and industrial output targtes appear too high to allow time to install more advanced equipment.
None of Gorbachev's proposals would change the system of economic incentives that has discouraged innovation and technological change, teh report added.

"The first significant resistance to specific policies, although not overall gaols, surfaced (in 1986) in both the massive government and party bureaucracy, particularly among enterprise managers who complained that they were being asked to carry out conflicting goals -- such as to raise quality standards and output targets simultaneously," the report said.
The CIA-DIA report predicted two ot three pct growth in the Soviet economy over the next several years.
It said the Soviet Union tariled the U.S. by seven to 12 years in advanced manufacturing technologies, such as computers and microprocessors.

Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said Congress would consider limiting the use fo generic commodity certificates as a means of cutting government spending.

"I suspect that as we go into some of the budget debates we're going to have on teh floor, this is going to be part of it," Leahy said, referring to proposals that the U.S. Agriculture Department save money by substituting cash outlays for payment-in-kind, or PIK, certificates in price and income support programs.

"I have a feeling that the PIK program, however the cost is defined, is going to be oen of the top number of areas that people are going to be looking for savings," Leahy told a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the government could save 1.4 billion dlrs during fiscal years 1988-92 if it curbed the use of generic certificates by banning so-called "PIK and roll" transactions.
Several Democratic senators had hasrh comments for generic certificates.
"We're trying to take care of a bad situation -- surpluses--by depressing the pric.e
I don't see any benefits," said Sen. Tom Harkni (D-Iowa).
"I don't see any benefit in driving their prices lower, lower, lower all teh time."
But Sen. Rudy Boschwitz said he supported use fo certificates.
"By and large I'm favorably impressed by PIK certifictaes.
I feel they have bene helpful," said Boschwitz.
As expected, officials from the General Accounting Office and the U.S. Agriculture Department indicated their estimates of the cots of PIK certificates compared to cash outlays were far apart.
The General Accounting Office, GAO, told the committee that PIK certificates increased total Commodity Credit Corp outlays through 1978 by between 107 mln and 653 mln dlrs.
GAO said that increase was offset by commodity storage cost savings of beween 169 mln and 253 mln dlr.s

Pressed by the committee, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley said government spending probably was about 450 mln dlrs above what it would have been had all program payments been made in cash, not counting storage savings.
Crowley also said he thought PIK certificates had lowered the price of corn adn boosted domestic consumption of corn.
Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz told the committee that the additional costs of using PKI certificates and storage, handling and transportation costs "balance off very closely."
Amstutz said he estimated the net cost of using certificates was about one ptc higher than using only cash to make program payments.

iWlliam Bailey, USDA deputy administrator for program planning, said there were "one hundred issues I find either incorrect (in the GAO report), disagree with or where their (GAO) facts are inconsistent with what's going on."
mAstutz said GAO had not given USDA the option of "providing input" into the preparation of their report "as they frequently do."

hTe USDA undersecretary also conceded that certificates and marketing loans had the similar effect of "putting more goods into the market," but that while the department supported certificates, it would continue to oppose a marketing loan for wheat and feedgrains because it would cost too much.

Angola's U.S.-backed UNITA rebel group has offered to reopen the Benguela railroad that runs through UNITA-held territory and linsk landlocked Zaire and Zambia to the Angolan port of Lobito.

The offer of a rail route to the Atlatnic would help South Africa's black neighbors reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.

Federal Reserve data released today indicate htat there has been no policy change in recent weeks and that none is likely at next week's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, economists said.

"The Fed continues to be accommodative ni its provision of reserves, indicating that there has been no policy shift since the beginning of this year," said Harold Nathan, economist at Wells Fargo Bank.
"These numbers and other things suggest the FOMC will not change polic,y" said Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. "The Fed is sitting fairly pretty now.

There's no real reason for it to change policy," said Joseph Liro of S.G. Warburg and Co Inc. Liro said the economy is shwoing moderate growth and does not require immediate policy easing and the money aggregates may well end March at the bottom of their target ranges.
All of the economists agreed that the Fed's major concern now si recent weakness in the dollar which early this week was heavily supported by central banks.
They said fear of hurting the dollar will cause the Fed ot be cautious in lowering interest rates further.
Numbers released by the Fed today were all in line with expectations and simliar to the data for most of this year.
The Fed said that banks' net free reserves averaged 603 mln dlrs in teh two-week statement period that ended on Wednesday versus 749 mln dlrs in the previous period.
In the single week to Wednesday, banks' borrowings at the discount window, less extended credits, averaged 302 mln dlrs compared with 228 mln dlrs in the firts week of the statement period.
Meanwhile the Federal funds rate average edgde up to 6.14 pct from 6.08 pct.
The Fed's failure to add reserves in the market on Tuesday and Wednesday surprised some, but economists said the data released today suggest it ahd no real need to add reserves.

The Fed's absenec may be explained by the lack of any pressing need for it to supply reserves and by a desire to boost borrowings in the second week of the statement period to meet its borrowings target, said Liro of Warburg.
Liro asid the Fed probably is shooting for a two-week borrowings average of 300-325 mln dlrs.
The obrrowings actually averaged 265 mln dlrs in the latest statement period and that was up from 191 mln dlrs in the prior period.
Brusca fo Nikko agreed that the Fed probably is aiming for two-week average discount window borrowings of around 300 mln dlrs.
He said that would correspond to a Federal funsd rate of around 6.10 pct.
It is nearly impossible for the Fed to hit any borrowings target since the demand for excess reserves is erratic, said Wells Fargo's Nathan.
He said the Fed is focusing instead on the funds rate and is trying to keep ti roughly within a six to 6-1/4 pct band.
Upward funds rate pressure and a big reserve-adding need are anticipated for the statement period that begna today.
More Brusca believes the Fed will have to add 3.5 to four billion dlrs a day ni reserves in this statement period.
Liro puts the add need at aronud 3.9 billion dlrs.
To partly address this requirement, many expect the Fed to add permanent reservse with effect next Thursday by offering to buy all maturities of Treasury bills on Wednesday.
A similar coupon "pass" may be requirde later.
There will be a greater demand for funds in this statement period becuase it includes the close of the quarter.
Further upward pressure on the Federal funds rate may come from window dressign demand as the Japanese fiscal year ends on March 31.
uSbstantial difficulties faced by the U.S. farm credit system can be solved with a business-like approach to the problems, a Farm Credit Admimistration official said.
Marvin R. Duncan, a member of the administration board, said the famr credit system faces unprecedented difficulties in its 70-year history.
Addressing Chicago business and agricultural economists, Duncan outlined three basic problems fo the farm credit system.
Those include the high cost of its debt, the quality of ist assets, and the management of its credit delivery system.
He said some of the system's debt carries interest rates as hihg as 15.65 pct and will not mature until the year 2007.
Of its 54.6 mln dlrs in assets, 24.1 pct are non-accrual, high risk or already forfeited property, which led to losses in 1986 fo 1.9 billion dlrs and in 1985 of 2.7 billion dlrs.
Problems with credit delivery have been somewhat resolve,d he said.

"The system is still plagued with duplication in layers of management and decision-making, inadequate tailoring of credit services to fit the emerging market, a large investment in bricks and mortar, adn a management and directorate more insular to the marketplace than that of its competitors," he said.
He said solutions to the problems should - - provide assurances to farmers on borrowers stokc and the stability of the farm credit system.
- maintain confidence of investors who buy sysetm securities.
- address the high cost fo the system's existing debt.
- enable the Farm Credit System Capital Corporation to carry out ist role as a workout bank.

Frank Naylor, chairman of the Farm Credit Administration, said this week that the system may lose as much as 1.4 billion dlrs this year, and another board member, Jim Billington, said Congress should plan to spend at least 800 mln dlrs beginning late this year to bali out the system.
Duncan noted that the system has about 70 billion dlrs in assets, serves about 800,000 individual borrowers and 3,000 cooperatives, and has 62.5 billino dlrs in securities outstanding.
"With a business-like solution to its problems, it can continue that role for generations into the future", he said.

The United States' emphasis on its foregin trade deficit is misplaced and the country's real problem lies in its large federal budget deficit, the General Agreeement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) said.
By stressing its record trade deficit of 169.8 billion dlrs last year, the U.S. Was fuelling protectionist perssure which threatens the world trading system, it said in an annual report.
The fundamental problem, the size of the U.S. Federal budget deficit, could be remedied only by cutting governmetn spending or encouraging personal savings to finance the debt, it said.
GATT also predicted world trade would grow by only 25. pct in 1987 -- a full percentage point lower than in each of the previous two years.

GATT experts urged Washington to resist protectionism and instead seke macroeconomic changes to reduce the current account payments deficit -- higher private savings, lower investment and a smaller federal budget deficit.
Raising U.S. Trade barriers "would result in little or on reduction in the current account deficit.
It would, however, increase infltaion and reduce world trade," it said.
"The basic cause -- some combination of insufficient domestic savings and an excessive budget deficit -- would remani," the report said.

GATT economists said trade expansion would slow this year because of slower growth forecasts in Japan and some West European nations as they adjust production and workforces to a low dollar, risk of higher U.S. Inflation, concerns over Third World debt management adn looming protectionism.
The report also said imbalances in the current accounts of Japan, West Germany and the U.S. Had increasde in 1986.
The most likely explanation was that exchange rate changes were not backed by changes in macroeconomic policies, ti added.
"Thus the prediction that tehse imbalances would be reduced as a result of the major realignment of exchange rates was not borne out last year," the report said.
GATT warned there was a risk of a sizeable increase in the U.S. Inflation rate under the combined impact of a rapidly expadning money supply and low dollar.
"Such a development could worsen the business climate by increasing uncertainty and pushing up interest rates, which, in turn, would adversely affect wolrd trade."
But the report noted a surprising rise in imports to the United States, despite the dollar's depreciation which makes foreign products more expesnive.
It suggested that resources idle in the U.S., Both human and in underutilised factories, were not geared to produce the goods and servcies sought from abroad.
World trade in mnaufactures grew by only three pct in 1986, about half of the rate of the previous year.
Trade in agricultural ogods expanded by just one pct, continuing a stagnant pattern in that sector this decade, GATT said.
Developing countries' exports dcelined significantly, while their imports increased moderately, although full statistics are not available yet, GATT said.
The combined export eranings of 16 major indebted nations were sharply lower, and only five of them (Chile, Colombia, Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand) had higher exports.

Bolivian rpesident Victor Paz Estenssoro will propose to Andean Pact countries a summit meeting with U.S. President Reagan to take place in Venezuela in May, foreign minister Guillermo Bedregal announced.
He otld reporters that the summit "if everything goes well" will possibly take place in one or two months.
"We rae coordinating an eventual meeting of the Andean Pact presidents and President Reagan, which could take place in Venezuela in May", he said.
The proposal is part of Bolivia's intention to relaunch the Andean Pact, he addde.

The Andean Pact, formed by Colombia, Venezuela, Peru and Ecuador, is a sub-regional economic group set up in 1969 to counteract economic progress of other more developed South Americna countries, such as Argentina and Brazil.
New Zealand's budget deficit for fiscal 1986/87 ending March 31 is expected to be aronud the budget forecast of 2.45 billion N.Z.
Dlrs but below a December forecast fo 2.91 billion, Finance Minister Roger Douglas said.

"It is clear now that the March tax flow has been considerably stronger than expected in some areas, particulalry provisional and terminal tax..," Douglas said in a statement.

Overall tax revenue is now expected to be around 600 mln dlrs above forecast, though there is some uncertainty about revenue from the final goods and services tax and March income tax payments, he adde.d
"Net expenditure also appears to be tracking to end-of-year forecast with the expectation thta over-expenditure in some areas will be offset by under-expenditure in others," he added.
Northwest Aluminum Co said it will open a second pot line in mid-May, bringign the smelter here to 80 pct of its production capacity.
Northwest Aluminum President Brett Wilcox, who leased the 30-year-old smelter from Martin Marietta Cor.p, said production would increase from around 45 tons a year at present to just over 70 tons.

The Bank fo Japan will sell today 400 billion yen of government financing bills in a 24-day repurchase agreement due April 20 to soak up a projected money market surplus, money traders said.

Japan's consumer price index (base 1985) was unchanged at 99.7 ni February from a month earlier, the government's Management and Coodination Agency said.

The February index was down one pct from a year ealrier for the third consecutive year-on-year drop.

nI February petrol prices increased but winter clothing prices stayed low and vegetable prices fell.

New Zealand's official foreign reserves fell slightly ot 7.13 billion N.Z.
Dlrs in February from 7.15 billion in January but were sharply above 2.85 billion in Februayr 1986, the Reserve Bank said in its weekly statistical release.
The White House Economic Policy Council decided to recommend trade sanctions against Japan for violations of the U.S.-Japanese semiconductor agreement, industry sourcse said.
They would give no details, noting that the White House had not commented no the decision.
The administration has been under pressure ot retaliate.

There was no immediate announcement on the council's decision, but U.S. Officials said it was likely the senior policy group's move on curbs reflected growing American frustratino over alleged unfair Japanese trade practices.
U.S. Officials said President Reagan would probably cat on the recommendations in a day or so, after consulting with aides on the foreign policy implications of retaliation.
The officials said Reagan might delay retaliation ofr a last try to persuade Japan to abide by the agreement reached last July governing trade in semiconductors.
Under a pact reached last July, Japan aws to stop dumping semiconductors in world markets and to open its own market to U.S.-made semiconductors.
In rteurn, the U.S.
Agreed to hold pu imposing anti-dumping duties on Japanese semiconductor shipments.
The United States said that dumping has stopped in the U.S. Market but has continued in third countries, and that teh Japanese market remains closed.
The pressure on Reagan to retaliate included a unanimous call by the Senate last week to impose penalties on Japanese hgih technology products containing semiconductors.
A call for retaliation also came form the semiconductor industry and from its chief trade union.
U.S. Officials said the most likely move against Japan would involve duties on semiconductor-based goods, such as televisions, video cassette recordesr and computers.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will make an official week-long visit to the United States form April 29 and hold talks in Washington with President Reagan, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masaharu Gotoda told reporters.

Mexico denied reports htat British banks are resisting signing a 76 billion dlr new loan and rescheduling package.
In a statement, the Finance Ministry said the process for formalizing the packaeg was going as planned.

Banking sources in London had been quoted earlier as saying the British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billion dlr loan contained in the deal.
However, the Finance Ministry statement said all the British banks had promised theri participation in the loan.

The ministry said Citibank, which chairs Mexico's bank advisory committee, has received cables from the British banks "confirmnig said commitment."
The ministry said the books on the package would be closed by mid-April and the first 3.5 billoin dlrs of the new money should arrive by the end of the month.
It also said French, Swiss and "some" Canadian banks had subscribed to the package and that the remainign Canadian banks would sign the accord in the next few days.

Taiwan's Central Bank will issue 12 billion aTiwan dlrs worth of savings bonds on April 13 to help curb M-1b money supply, which rose by a seasonally adjusted 48.22 pct in the year to end-February, a bank spokesman told Reuters.

nIdia is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cut its trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all no offer in return for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Tradnig Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promtoe Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One rtade source said India has targetted countries that depend on an Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

However, countertrade edals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade cacounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, official figures show.
However, hte figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, the sources said.

Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms adn crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, against three billion in 1985/86.

Indian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to hepl narrow the country's large trade deficit, is still insignificant compared with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the trade sources said.
The trade deficit, which hit an estimated record 6.69 billion dlrs in 1985/86, is expected to decline to 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But the push to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including teh slow growth of foreign reserves, a tight debt repayment schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One source said India si showing more dynamism in promoting countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetly because they break GATT rules.
As a member of hte General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), India cannot officially support bartering.
The MMTC's recent countertrade daels include iron ore exports to Yugoslavia for steel structures and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders now include a clause taht preference will be given to parties who accept payment in kind for goods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexible.
"We also take nito account other factors such as prices at which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade official said.

Early this year the commerce ministry quietly otld foreign companies interested in selling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the point, hte official said a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Commission.
In return, the oSuth Koreans gave a verbal assurance to buy Indian goods worth 10 pct of the contract, against the 25 pct sought by New Delhi, the trade official said.
"We selected the Korean firm beacuse its bid was the lowest," he added.
Countertrade is helping African countries shrot of foreign currency to import goods.
India has signed a trade protocol to buy up to 15,000 tonnes of asbestos fibre from Zimbabwe in exchange for Indian goods, including jute bags and cars.
But despite India's new drive, countretrade has some inherent problems, they added.
"It is not always easy to meet the basic requirement that teh trade should always be balanced," one trade source said.
"The other problem si it is often difficult to supply or buy commodities which the other party wants."
nAother added, "Barter is also restrictive.
We look upon ti as a temporary measure to get over the current balance of payments difficulty.
"This si why countertrade has not been made a law in India.
It odes not even figure in the country's foreign trade policy."

<Nippon Telegraph and eTlephone Co> (NTT) is considering buying a Cray II supercomputer worth some three billion yen from Cray Research Inc <CYR>, and a decision is expected in early April, an NTT official said.

The finance ministry appears ready ot allow Japanese financial institutions to use overseas financial futures markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say when, but banking sources expect approval sa early as April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance companies are expected to become eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock idnex futures.
Ministry officials said they rae wary of giving permission to individuals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents yb financial institutions would be prohibited as securities exchange laws bar banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches fo Japanese banks and securities houses have already been allowed to use the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance bsaed on Foreign Exchange Administration Law will have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has told his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with a draft economic package in early April in time for his visit to Washingotn starting on April 29, government officials said.

Nakasone also instructed the government's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) to work closer with the LDP to work out a full-fledged economic plan to boost domestic demand as pledged at lats month's Paris currency stability accord by six industrial countries, the officials told Reuters.

The date for the government to announce its package, based on the LDP's suggested measures, is not yte known but it may be before the fiscal 1987 budget passes the Parliament around late May, the officials said.
The government has said in the past the packgae should come after the passage of the budget.

But calls have grown at home and abroad for the government to announce it earlier as budget debaets have been stalled by an opposition boycott of parliamentary business in protest at a planned five pct sales tax.
EPA chief Tetsuo Kondo told a press conference he sees a need to work on the economic plna early although the government's stance on the date for the plan remains the same, an EPA spokesman said.
Projected measures include promoting house construction, infrastructure and urban development, he quoted Kondo as syaing.
Under last month's Paris currency agreement, Japan promised to work out a comprehensive economic plan to stimulate domestic demand, increase imports and so help reduce its huge trade suprlus.
The government announced today Naaksone will visit Washington on April 29 for a week to discuss bilateral issues, including the trade imbalance, with President Reagan and other officials.
The <British Petroleum Co of Australia Ltd> reported a 16.15 mln dlr ent loss for 1986 against a 73.38 mln dlr profit in 1985 after sales fell to 2.27 billion dlrs from 2.94 billion.
The British Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> unit attributed the deficit to stock lsoses arising from the drop in crude prices in the first half, when it made a 119.93 mln dlr loss.

It said government compensation, in the form of subsidies to refiners to paritally cover stock losses, together with improved crude prices in the second half, enabled the group's oil business to make a modest pre-tax profit.
BP Australia said ti had not recommended a dividend.

Japan's Nissan Motor Co Ltd said it and <Lancer Boss Group Ltd> of the U.K. Haev agreed to cooperate on the design and manufacture of forklift trucks.

Under the accord, Lancer will start making jointly designed trucks at its plant in Moosburg, Wets Germany, from July with production reaching 300 three-wheeled and 100 four-wheeled trucks by end-March 1988.
Output will be doubled from April 1, 198,8 a Nissan spokeswoman said.
Nissan will start selling the three-wheelers under its brand-name later this year and the four-wheelers from the end of 1987, teh company said.
The equipment manufacturing agreement with Lancer is a precaution against the European Community's (EC) January 1987 restriction on forklift truck exports ot the EC, industry sources said.
Nissan exports 70 pct of its annual output of 16,000 forklift trucks, shipping 2,548 units to the EC in 1986, the spokeswomna said.
The Finance Ministry is expected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, from October 1 in response to growing calls from corporations, imnistry sources said.

rAound 200 corporations satisfy financial standards set by securities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp> and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managers said.
oMst eligible firms would have to set up special reserves for CP issues called backup lines, or be guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
hTe legal status of yen CP would be the same as yen commercial bills and it would be placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
hTe minimum issue unit will be 100 mln yen, and maturities will be from 30 days and six months, they said.
Securities houses, banks, insurance companies and conusmer credit companies are barred from CP issues, they said.
Only banks may eb commissioned to handle the clerical business of principle payments, they added.

Four major Japanese steelmakers plan to form a seamless pipe export cartel ofr markets other than the U.S. And the European Community for a year from April to keep prices above output costs, company officials involved said.

The companies are Nippon steel Corp <NSTC.T>, Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd <SMIT.T>, Nippon Kokan KK <NKKT.T> and Kawasaki Steel Corp <KAWST.>, which together account for some 95 pct of Japan's total seamless pipe exports.
The firms will apply to form the cartel to the Minisrty of International Trade and Industry today and approval is expected later this month, the officials said.

Under the plan, the four companies will set floor prices for exports as prices have fallen sharply due to the ye'ns appreciation against the dollar, reduced world demand caused by lower oil prices and excess domestic capacity which resulted in price-cutting competition, the officials said.
In calendar 1986, seamless pipe exports flel to 2.34 mln tonnes from 2.99 mln in 1985 and 3.12 mln in 1981.
The officials declined to give any idea of floor prices, saying it depensd partly on volume, but industry sources estimate average export prices would rise by around 20 pct to some 800 dlrs a tonne.
The president of Japan's biggest high technology firm, NEC Corp <NIPN.T>, si anything but worried, despite growing anti-Japanese protectionism, a soaring yen, and a stagnant world electronics market.
"The company's structure was developed by looikng ahead," Tadahiro Sekimoto told Reuters in an interview.
"We assumed the era of a strong yen, trade friction and globalisation woudl arrive, and we moved ahead on that basis.
There's no need to change our strateyg now."
However, the world's largest manufacturer of microchips, the tiny silicon wafers which aer the brains of most high technology products, knows it must keep looking ahead if it is to survive.
Hoping to build on exsiting strengths, NEC is now turning its focus on home electronics, an area of past weakness, Sekimoto said.
NEC wants to follow tis corporate slogan "C and C" (Computers and Communications) to create high level home electronics that go beyond mere televisions and video tape recorders, Sekimoto said.
Home electronics accounted for olny eight pct of NEC's total 2,334.67 billion yen sales on a consolidated basis in the year ended March 31, 1986.
Industry analysts say NEC si wise to target what will be a major growth market in the future, but some warn the company faces some stiff competition.

"This is where the market is going to be for a long time -- in products that combnie personal computers, video display and telecommunications networks," said Salomon Brothers (Asia) Ltd analyst Carole Ryavec.
"But Matsushita (Electric Industrial Co Ltd) may be theer first."
But Sekimoto argues that NEC's overall strengths will caryr the day.
"Many companies are in the top 10 in computers or microchips or telecommunications, but none is in teh top 10 in all three.
NEC is unique in thta respect," he said.
To help its already high rankings, NEC will further increase the high level of offshore production which makes it one of teh most multinational of Japan's electronics firms.
The company will increase offshore output of all goods it sells overseas to 50 pct from a current 25 pct over teh next several years, Sekimoto said.

But the firm plans to go it alone in expanding overseas, despite moving last year to become joint owner, along with Franc'es Cie des Machines Bull <BULP.P>, of U.S. Firm Honeywell Inc's <HON> Information Systems unit.
"We hope to increase our share in the U.S. Market throuhg the Honeywell tie-up.
But our basic strategy is to take an independnet and autonomous route," said Sekimoto.
The company also plans to maintain its independent line by continuing to make computers which are not compatibel with those of International Business Machines Corp <IBM>, he said.
"Among the Japanese competitors, only NEC hasn't been caught in software copyright disputes with IBM and our proftis and market share have gradually expanded," Sekimoto said.
Once new ways of linking non-compatible computers are perfecte,d IBM compatibility will be irrelevant.
"What will matter is the best hardware, the best software and the best ability to meet customers need,s" Sekimoto said.

In fact, NEC, which has over half of Japan's personal computer market, may go ot court to stop competitors selling cheaper machines which can run NEC software but infringe copyright on its operating system, an NEC spokesman said.
While industry analysts give NEC high marks ofr looking ahead, they note that it failed in forecasting microchip demand.
Like other Japanese chipmakers, the firm was lfet with serious excess capacity when lean years followed the boom times.
But after two years of cutbacks in cpaital investment in the sector, Sekimoto thinks the time has come to boost spending again, if only slightly.
"We're ont going to increase production.
But we are going to invest in enw product development and upgrade existing plant," he said.
Despite NEC's admitted strnegths, analysts note the company faces tough times due to stagnant markets.
"NEC has excellent worldwide capacity and technology, ubt they are caught in a downturn which may last a long time," said Salamon's Ryavec.

The company forecasts such troubles will slash parent net profits to 30 billion yen in hte year ending March 31, 1987, down 43 pct from the previous year, although sales are expected to rise eight pct to 2,130 billion yen.
Profits will improve only slightly next year, rsiing to 38 billion yen on sales of 2,350 billion, it said.
The government adopted an 8,829 billion yen stop-gap budget for fiscal 1987 starting Aprli 1 to compensate for the delay in the passage through the Parliament of the full 1987/88 budget.

The provisional budget includes 1,862 billion yen in public works spending to help stimulate the economy and meet overseas demand for Japan to import more and reduce ist huge trade surplus, officials said.
They said the stop-gap budget will be in effect for 50 days through Mya 20 and is the largest ever.
The budget includes 1,580 billion yen in new government bodn issues.
Officials said the spending on public works accounts for about two-sevenths of the 6,017 billion yen in public works outlya set aside in the pending formal 1987/88 budget.
The planned full budget totals 54,101 billion ye.n
The government had to work out the stop-gap budget because budget debates have been delayed by an opposition boycott fo Parliamentary business in protest against a planned five pct sales tax.

Japan's industrial production index (base 1980) rose 0.3 pct to a seasonally adjusted 122.7 in February from the previous month, the Ministry of Internationla Trade and Industry said.

The preliminary, unadjusted February index rose 0.6 pct from a year earlier after a 0.5 pct year-on-year rise in January The adjusted February producers' shipment index (base 1980) rose 0.7 pct to 1185. from January when it fell 0.7 pct from December.

A 2.7 pct rise by the electronics industry on higher output of facsimile machines and video taep recorders was a major contributor to the rise in February industrial output, though car production fell from January.

A Tokyo Medical College group said it had developed a five-imnute method that may be the world's fastest way of screening people for the AIDS virus.

The February increase over a year earlier reflected a 23.9 pct rise in orders from non-manufacturing industries, absorbing a 10.8 pct drop in htose from manufacturers.

The Australian government telecommunications authority, Telecom Australia, said ti will offer two bond maturities totalling 40 mln Australian dlrs for tender next week.

South Korea plans to increase the size of its budget in 1988 by 11 to 12 pct from this year's 15,569 billion won, Economic Planning Board officials said.

The proposed boost is based on a government forecast that gross national product (gnp) will grow by more than 7.5 pct and the gnp deflator by 3.5 pct in 1988, against targets of 8.0 pct and 3.5 pct respectively this year, thye said.
Details of the 1988 budget, in which spending will macth revenue, have yet to be worked out, the officials said.
The balanced budget in 1986 totalled 13,800.5 billion wno.
Australia's ruling Labour Party is seriously considering a snap poll in May with the opposition in disarray after a leadership crisis, paryt officials said.
The election was discussed at a meeting of senior government advisers and leaders in Canberra last night, but a final decision si pending, the officials said.

Prime Minister Bob Hawke has said he prefers to wait until his term ends in early 1988, but the officials said he might be persuaded to call a poll as early as May 9, a week before a promised tough mini-budget.
Public opinion polls give Labour a clera edge over the opposition Liberal-National coalition.
Jardine Matheson Hlodings Ltd <JARD.HKG> said it planned a bonus issue of four new "B" shares of 20 H.K.
Cents aech for every ordinary share of par value two dlrs.
A company statement said the firm expects to pay a total 1987 dividend of four cents per "B" share, whlie the "A" share dividend will be maintained at last year's level of 40 cents a share.
Jardine Matheson announced earlier a 205 pct jump in 1968 net profits to 479 mln dlrs from 157 mln in 1985.
Shareholders' funds increased to 5.20 billion dlrs from 4.77 billion in 1985, the statement said.

It quoted chairman Simon Keswick as saying Jardine Matheson achieved the good performance through satisfactory results in most sections, especially Hong Kong Land Co Ltd <HKLD.HKG>, Jardine Fleming Co Lt,d and its business in Japan.

He said the group's stake of about 35 pct in Hong Kong Land, which will be lowered to 26 pct after the completion of a reorganisation, is a" long term investment and now stands at a level which causes us no financial strain or problems of asset imbalance."

Keswick said the issue of new "B" shares will give the group "the flexibility in the future to issue ordinary shares for expansion without jeopardising the shareholding stabiltiy which has been brought about through the group's recent restructuring."
He said the new issue is pending approval from boht the firm's shareholders and warrant holders, adding an appropriate adjustment will be made to the warrant exercise price.
The Jardine group has nearly completed its reorganisation, with Jadrine Matheson transferring its control of Hk Land to the new unit <Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd>.

Jardine Strategic will also hold majority stakes in the two companies spun off from Hk Land -- <Mandarin Oriental Intenrational Ltd> and <Dairy Farm International Holdings Ltd> -- plus cross holdings with Jardine Matheson.
Jardine Matheson, which had debts of about 2.7 billion dlsr last year, will become debt free after the restructuring.
"A positive cash flow from operations and disposals, continuing into 1987, has transformed our balance shee,t" Keswick said.
He noted the firm last year sold interests in airfreight operations, Australian properties and trucking business, and its remainign U.S. Oil and gas activities.
Jardine Matheson decided to make a provision against its general trading business in the Middle East in view fo the continuing weakness of oil prices, Keswick said.
But he said the operations would be profitable in teh longer term.
He said the firm's function "has evolved into one primarily of strategy, structure and financila and personnel policy."
He said Jardine Matheson will reduce the size of the board fo directors but will simultaneously create a new Pacific regional board.
He gave no further details fo the change.
Jardine Matheson shares rose 20 cents to 24.90 dlrs at midday no the Hong Kong stock market.
In early trading it had fallen to 24.30 dlrs because of rumousr yesterday that the firm planned a rights issue.

The Brokne Hill Pty Co Ltd <BRKN.S> said it expects a strong full year result, helped by sigificant investment allowance credits in the fourth quarter, but net will fall short of the record 988.2 mln dlrs earned in 1985/86 ended May 31.
The group earlier reported its net earnings dropped to 603.0 mln dlrs in the first three quarters ended February 28 from 813.0 mln a year eariler.
Third quarter net fell to 206.0 mln dlrs from 238.6 mln a year earlier and 2203. mln in the second quarter ended November 31, BHP said in a statement.
Earnings in the first nine months were at the lower end of share analysts' forecasts yesterdya of a range of 600 mln to 620 mln dlrs.
BHP held its annual dividend unchanged at 37.5 cents after declaring a steady final dividend fo 20 cents and announced a one-for-five bonus issue to shareholders registered May 1.
The bonus is being made from reserves which will not qualify for tax-free distribution after teh introduction of dividend imputation next July 1.
The bonus shares will not rank for teh final dividend, BHP said.
BHP said it should not be expected that the present raet of dividend will be maintained on the increased capital.
The level of future dividends will be influenced by the impliactions of the proposed dividend imputation legislation, it said.
As previously reported, dividends will become tax-free in shareholders' hands proviedd they are paid out of profits that have borne the full 49 pct company tax rate.
BHP, which confined comment to the third quarter, siad petroleum net earnings dropped to 98.8 mln dlrs from 139.6 mln a year earlier, and steel profit to 27.0 mln from 48.8 mln.

BHP said the petroleum division earnings fall reflected generally lower oil prices and sales volumes from Bass Strait while the steel decline was due to a fiev pct fall in domestic sales and higher costs associated with the commissioning of new plant and some operational difficulties.
The rise in third quarter minerals net to 95.7 mln dlrs from 81.5 mln a year earlier largely reflected the increase in ownership of the Mt Newamn iron ore project, it said.
The 60.7 mln dlr extraordinary gain, all in the third term, reflected a 240.7 mln profit on the sale of <Blue Circel Southern Cement Ltd> offset by a U.S. Oil acreage writedown.
The Reserve Bank said it will not offer any rteasury notes for tender next week.

Japan's current account surplus rsoe to 7.38 billion dlrs in February from 3.89 billion a year ago and from 4.95 billion in January, the Finance Ministry said.
The trade surplus rose to 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 4.77 billion a year earlier and 5.07 billion in January.
The long-term capital account deficit widened to 11.40 billion dlrs from 8.06 billion a year ago, but ti narrowed from 12.32 billion in January, the Ministry said.
Japan's February exports rose to 16.74 billion dlrs from 14.89 billion in February 1986 and from 14.65 billoin in January, the Ministry said.
Imports fell to 8.61 billion from 10.12 billion a year earlier and 8.94 billion in Januar.y
The invisible rtade deficit fell to 617 mln dlrs in February from 693 mln a year earlier, but was up from a 527 mln deficit in January.

Transfer payments nrarowed to a 140 mln dlr deficit last month from a 185 mln deficit a year earlier and a 225 mln deficit in January.
The basic ablance of payments deficit in February fell to 4.02 billion dlrs from 4.17 billion in February 1986 and 7.37 billion in January.

The overall balance of payments deficit rose to 2.65 billion dlrs from 1.30 billion a year earlier but was down from 7.04 billion in Janaury.
The seasonally adjusted trade surplus flel to 9.16 billion dlrs in February from the record 9.58 billion in January, the Ministry said.
The seasonally adjusted current account sruplus also dropped to 8.4 billion dlrs in February from the record 8.83 billion set in January.

Department store and supermarket sales in February rose 3.7 pct from a year earlier to 1,080 billion yen, after a 2.6 pct year-on-year gain in January, boosted by higher sales of clothes and food at department stores, the Ministry of International Trade adn Industry said.
The unadjusted total included department store sales of 559 billion yen, up 5.1 pct from a year earlier, and supermarket sales fo 521 billion, up 2.4 pct.
The seasonally adjusted store sales index (base 1985) fell 1.5 pct to a preliminary 106.7 in February from 108.3 in January comapred with 102.9 a year earlier.

The Philippines will ask the U.S. Agriculture Department (USDA) to increase its 1987 sugar import quota following market reports that Tawian will not be able to fulfil its quota, Sugar Regulation Administration (SRA) chairman Arsenim Yulo said.
Yulo told Reuters the SRA would also protest a USDA moev to award Taiwan's shortfall to the Dominican Republic.
hTe Dominican Republic already has a larger sugar quota, Yulo said.
"Any aTiwanese shortfall should be awarded to the Philippines or at the least we should share a hike with the Dominican Republic."
The SUDA last December listed 1987 sugar import quota allocations for the Dominican Republic at 160,160 short tons and for Taiwan at 10,920 short tons.
The hPilippines has said it was badly hit by a cut in its quota to 143,780 short tons from 231,660 in 1986.

The U.S. Has approved the sale fo a U.S.-made supercomputer to India while rejecting its request for a more powerful model, the New York Times reported.

India wanted to buy a powerful supercomputer, such as the Cray X-MP with wto processors running in tandem, but the Times said U.S. Officials offered a choice of machines with a single processor, several generations behind the Cray X-MP.
The paper, citing unnamed U.S. Officials, said the Indian government was told of hte decision last week, but has so far given no formal indication that it is interested in the type offered.
India had asked the U.S. For na modern supercomputer which it indicated would be used for scientific purposes, notably sophisticated weather forecasting.
However, India's close ties wtih the Soviet Union remains the main reason why the U.S. Has restricted the sale of its state-of-the-art computer technology to India, the Times said.
U.S. Defence officials are patriculalry concerned the Soviet Union could gain access to the supercomputer and use it to decipher high-level U.S.
Codes, while ohters say the computer could be very useful in designing nuclear weapons.
<United States Lines Inc> has laid off 260 employees, almost its entire Far East staff, ist Hong Kong office general manager Elliott Burnside told Reuters.

hSipping companies, subject to approval by their boards.

Fisons Plc <FISN.L> said it planned to raise abuot 110 mln stg through an international placing of up to 18 mln new shares, mainly in Europe and the Far East.

Outgoing United States Ambassador Stephen Bowsorth told a news conference he did not think the Philippines would follow Brazil's example and suspend interest payments on foreign loans from commercial banks.
"I see no eviednce that the Philippine government even contemplates doing that.
It has said at the outset that it accepts the legitimacy of these debts and it si determined over time to meet its obligations fully," he said.
Philippine officials and a 12-bank committee have been meeting for the past four weeks in New Yokr in a bid to reschedule 9.4 billion dlrs of foreign debt.
Bosworth said the United States strongly supports Manila's bid to put its international financial situation in ordre and that the private bank creditors were aware of that.
"I think there si no question that the private banks are aware of the views of the U.S. Government ...
I am confident htey will take those views into account when they make their own decisions," Bosworth said.
eH added: "These are private banks.
They are responsible ot their shareholders and they have to make their decisions on their own.
But I am confident they understand the views of the United States and our strong support".

Sri Lankan Food Department officials said the U.S. Department of Agriculture rejected a U.S. Firm's offer of 80 U.S. Dlrs per tonne CAF to supply 52,500 tonnes of soft wheat to Colombo from teh Pacific Northwest.
They said Sri Lanka's Food Department subsequently made a counter-offer to five U.S. Firsm to buy wheat at 85 U.S. Dlrs CAF for April 8-16 delivery.
The company which obtains USDA approval for the proposed price must inform the Departemnt before 1330 gmt, they said.

Philippine sugar production in the 1987/88 crop year ending August has been set at 1.6 mln tonnes, up from a provisional 1.3 mln tonnes this year, Sugar Regulaotry Administration (SRA) chairman Arsenio Yulo said.
Yulo told Reuters a survey during the current milling season, which ends next monht, showed the 1986/87 estimate would almost certainly be met.
He said at least 1.2 mln tonnes of the 1978/88 crop would be earmarked for domestic consumption.
Yulo said about 130,000 tonnes would be set aside fro the U.S. Sugar quota, 150,000 tonnes for strategic reserves and 50,000 tonnes would be sold on the world market.
He said if the government approved a long-standing SRA recommendation to manufacture ethanol, the project would take up another 150,000 tonnes, slightly raising the target.
"The government, for its own reasons, ahs been delaying approval of the project, but we expect it to come through by July," Yulo said.
Ethanol could make up five pct fo gasoline, cutting the oil import bill by about 300 mln pesos.
Yulo said three major Philippine distilleries wree ready to start manufacturing ethanol if the project was approved.
The ethanol project would result in employment for about 100,000 people, sharply reducing those thrown otu of work by depressed world sugar prices and a moribund domestic industry.
Production quotas, set for the first time in 1987/88, had been submitted to President Corazon Aqunio.
"I think the President would rather wait till the new Congress convenes after the May electiosn," he said.
"But there is really no need for suhc quotas.
We are right now producing just slightly ovre our own consumption level."
"The producers have never enjoyed such high prices," Yulo said, adidng sugar was currently selling locally for 320 pesos per picul, up from 190 pesos last August.
Yulo said prices were driven up because of speculation following teh SRA's bid to control production.

"We are no longer concerned so much with the world market," he said, adding producers in the Negros region had learned from their mistakes and diversified into conr and prawn farming and cloth production.
He said diversification into products other thna ethanol was also possible within the sugar industry.
"The Brazilians long ago learnt theri lessons," Yulo said.
"They have 300 sugar mills, compared with our 41, but they relocated many fo them and diversified production.
We want to call this a 'sugaracne industry' instead of the sugar industry."
He said sugarcane could be fed to pigs and livestock, used for thatching roosf, or used in room panelling.
"When you cut sugracane you don't even have to produce sugar," he said.
Yulo said the Philippines was lobbying for a renewal of the International Sugar Agreemnet, which expired in 1984.
"As a major sugar producer we are urging them to write a new agreemnet which would revive world prices," Yulo said.
"If there is no agreement world prices will always be depressed, particularly because the European Community is subsidising its producers and dumping sugar on the market.s"
He said current world prices, holding steady at about 7.60 cents per pound, were uneconomical for the Philippines, where production costs ranged from 12 to 41 cents a pound.
"If hte price holds steady for a while at 7.60 cents I expect the level to rise to about 11 cents a pound by the end of this year," he said.
uYlo said economists forecast a bullish sugar market by 1990, with world consumption outstripping production.
He asid sugar markets were holding up despite encroachments from artificial sweeteners and high-fructose corn syrup.
B"ut we are not happy with the Reagan Administration," he said.
"Since 1935 we hvae been regular suppliers of sugar to the U.S.
In 1982, when they restored the quota ssytem, they cut ours in half without any justification."
Manila was keenly watching Washington's moves to uct domestic support prices to 12 cents a pound from 18 cents.
The U.S. Agriculture Department last December slashed tis 12 month 1987 sugar import quota from the Philippines to 143,780 short tons from 231,660 short tons in 1986.
uYlo said despite next year's increased production target, some Philippine mills were expected to shut down.
"tA least four of the 41 mills were not working during the 1986/87 season," he said.
"We expect two or three more to follow suit during the enxt season."
eMtallgesellschaft AG <METG.F> said it is founding a company to work in commodities futures and options trading and financial services linked to these.

Mitsubishi Corp <MITT.TOK> said it has taken a 25 pct stake worth five mln krone in <Danish Dairy Farms Ltd> and will jointly market its produce frmo April.

aJpan has sought to assure the U.S.
It si not trying to keep foreign equity in a new Japanese international telecommunications company below the legal limit of 33 pct, a Post and Telecommunications ministry official said.

In a letter sent yesterday, Postal Minister Shunjiro Karasawa tlod U.S. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige that the ministry does not object to foreign participation by those U.S. Firms that have expressed interest.
But it deos oppose any foreign international telecommunications carrier having a management role, he said.

The move appears to be an effort to dampen U.S. Opposition to the planned merger of two rival firms seeking to compete with the current monopoly <Kokusai Denwa Denshin Co Ltd>, and to reduce the share hled in any KDD rival by U.K.'s Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L>, industry analysts and diplomats said.

One of the rival firms, <International Telecom Japan Inc> (ITJ) has offered a stake in the company to eight U.S. Firms including General Electric Co <GE>, Ford Motor oC <F> and Citibank NA <CCI), and two European companies, ITJ president Nobuo Ito said yesterday.
Cable and Wireless holds a 20 pct share in a second potential KDD rival, <International Digital Communications Planning Inc>, along with <C Itho and Co>.
Merrill Lynch and Co Inc <MER> and Pacific Telesis International Inc <PAC>, both of the U.S., Hold three and 10 pct shares respectivel.y
The Post and Telecommunications Ministry has urged the merger of the two firms because it says the market can only support a singel KDD competitor.
It has also rejected management participation by an intenrational common carrier, such as Cable and Wireless, arguing no international precedent for such a stake exists.

Cable and Wireless Director of Corporate Strategy, Jonathan Solomon, yesterday again told ministry officials he opposes a merger proposal that would limit Cable and Wireless' share to less than three pct adn total foreign participation to about 20 pct, the ministry official said.
Channeling the U.S. Firms into a single merged competitor would most probably result in diluting Cabel and Wireless' share, industry analysts said.
"Eventually the ministry will get what it wants -- one combined competitor," Bache Securities (Japan) Ldt analyst Darrell Whitten said.
Leverage may get the total foreign share up to a certain amount, but you won't fidn any one company with an extraordinarily large holding," Whitten said.
Western diplomatic sources were more blun.t
"They (the ministry) don't want to see Cable and Wireless with a reasonable share and they think of all sorts fo strategies to reduce that share," one said.

Fumio Watanabe, a senior Keidanren (a leading business organization) official who has been trying to arrange the merger, will presetn a new outline of his proposal on Thursday, the ministry official said.

Dlr revolving certificate of deposit (CD) issuanec facility, banking sources said.

Goode and Co Ltd> said CSR had till now been overlooked by many of the offshore investosr now heavily buying Australian gold and resource stocks.

<Avana Group Plc>, defending itself against a bid from Ranks Hovis McDougall Plc <RHML.L>, RHM, forecast a 3.4 mln stg rise ni profits in the 1986/87 year.

Botswana has stopped importing almost all meat products from Zimbbawe after reports of a suspected outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the neighbouring country.

The South fArican government's maize production estimate of 7.8 mln tonnes for the current year is "rather too conservative," leading grain and produce merchants Kahn and Kahn Pty Ltd said.

Italy's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow three pct in real terms this year and 2.7 pct ni 1988, said economic information company Data Resources Europe Inc (DRI).
Michel Girardin, DRI Europe's senior economist, said at a conference that Italian GDP growth this year "will eb mainly driven by consumption and especially investment."
Girardin said the driving force behind GDP growth next year will shift from domestic demand to exports sa a result of expected depreciation of the lira against the major currencies.
Italy's budget ministry said yestreday that GDP rose 2.7 pct in real terms in 1986.
DRI forecast that inflation, which was an average 6.3 ptc in 1986, will be under five pct this year and that interest rates should drop two pct.
Girardin said the lira is expected to appreciate 14 ptc against the dollar this year following last year's 22 pct appreciation.
An expected German mark appreciation against the dollar means thta the lira should lose about six pct of its value relative to the German currency, he said.
DRI estimates that foreign demand for Italian products shuold grow by a 3.2 pct this year following last year's 6.2 pct increase.
Japan today announced another mammoth monthly trade surplus thta economists said would be sure to intensify already mounting pressure on the country for action.
"The world ahs every reason to be furious with Japan for not moving more quickly," Jardine Fleming (Securities) Ltd economist Eric Rasmussen said.
The Finance Mniistry said today that the trade surplus soared to 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 5.7 billion in January and 4.77 billion a year ago.
The current cacount surplus, which includes trade in services as well as goods, climbed to 7.38 billion dlrs last month from 4.95 billion in January and 3.89 billion a year ago.
After ebing adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, the figures look a bit better, but not much.
On that basis, the trade surplus declined slightly in February to 9.16 billion dlrs from a recodr 9.58 billion in January.

"In the medium term we expect this modest improvement to continue but the pace of progress may be too slow to ward off further protectionism or further yen strength," said William Stirling, economist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. A strong yen would make Japanese goods more expensive on world markets while making imports into the countyr cheaper.
"On a seasonally adjusted basis, we appear to be making some progress on getting exports down," Jardines' Rasmussen said.
But imports do not seem to be picking up much because the Japanese economy remains sluggish, eh said.
Finance Ministry officials blamed last month's slower import growth on a decline ni oil imports as refiners worked off stocks they had built up in January.
The officials took comfort from a decline in the volume of exports lats month, after an unexpected year-on-year increase in January.
This means the effects of the two-year rise of the yen against teh U.S. Dollar are finally beginning to have an impact on exports, they said.
But economists warned that may not eb soon enough for Japan's trading partners.
Thyssen AG <THYH.F> said it expects to post a good profit in 1987 despite anticipated losses in its mass steel-making operations thsi year.
