The Construction Bank, which is oen of four specialist banks in China, focuses on infrastructure and heavy industrial projects.
The funds raised wlil partly finance two ethylene factories near Shanghai.
Construction of the plants, which are a major item in the current five year pla,n will begin soon.
The plants will cost more than 300 mnl dlrs.
The remainder of the funds will come frmo export credits and domestic borrowings.
Australian markets are booming sa foreign fund managers redirect capital away from the United States and other traditional markets, analysts said.

High short-term interest rates, a bullish stock market nad an increasingly stable currency reflect a massive inflow of fresh funds in the last two months, largely from Japanese and U.S. Investors, analysts polled by Reuters said.
Fund managers want quality mrakets to park their cash in and have settled on Australia, Britain and Canada as they diversify from volatile U.S. Dollar instruments, they said.
A one percentage point fall in key 10-year bonds rates in the past month, rceord share prices and a 10-month high for the currency of 0.71 U.S. Dlrs all illustrated the inflow.
Official figures on the latest inflow of invsetment capital are not available, but brokers said they received almost daily inquiries from Japan and the United States.
"These people have got trillions of dollars slohsing about and they don't know what to do with it.
Some of that is ending up here with the attraction fo high interest rates and reasonable currency stability," National Australia Bank Ltd economist Brian Hamley said.
"There is a 'flight to qualiyt'," Hamley said.
"Australia may not be in the best (economic) position, but three aren't too many other countries where you'd want to put your money."
The stronger Australian dollar was also attracting investors taking advantage of an appreciating currency against the volatiliyt of the U.S. Unit, analysts said.
"We're looking a more favoured market than perhaps the U.S. Where some people would be concerned about the valeu of the U.S. Dollar," Lloyds Bank NZA Ltd chief economist Will Buttrose said.
"Why not put the money in Australia where entry si cheap and the currency looks stable?"
But turning that capital into more permanent productive investment depedns on government economic policy, he said.

"It will only disappear if people lose confidence in the direction in the economy," Buttrose said, adding that offsohre investors would carefully watch the government's promised tough economic statement on May 14.

While happy to invest ni bonds and other vehicles yielding interest unobtainable elsewhere, fund managers could just as easily reverse the flow -- particularly the Japanese, who were badly hurt in the past by rapid falls in the Australian dollar and hefty jumps in bond rates, analysts said.
"It will reamin very edgy money.
If something was not to be delivered, if the statement wasn't consiedred tough enough, one might see a substantial outflow," Buttrose said.
Offshore investors are eager to see Australia take tough economic decisions to curb its 100 billion dlr foreign debt and stubborn current account deficit, analysts sadi.
"They rae giving us the benefit of the doubt and I think they would like to leave the money here," Buttrose said.
Reserve aBnk policy has also reflected the increased interest in investment in Australia and the need to shield Japanese investors from rapid currency fluctuations.

Reserve Governor Bob oJhnston last week acknowledged an element of targeting the rate against the yen in currency policy when he said authorities could not take their "eyes off the yen" because of the crucial role of Japanese investors.
Analysts asid they believed the Reserve Bank had worked successfully in recent months to keep the Australian dollar within the range of 100 to 103 yen.
Apart rfom its recovery against a weak U.S. Dollar, the Australian dollar has also risen almost three pct on a trade-weighted basis in the last three weeks.
Offshore buying has also played a role in the boomnig Australian share market.
It has followed Wall Street adn other markets, but is also setting its own trend in response to the weight of both domestic and offshore funds pouring into equities, particularly in the gold sector.
The key all ordinaries index orse to a record 1,758.3 today, nearly 20 pct above its level at the end of 1986, while the gold index has nearly doubled to a record 3,081.0 in the same period.

The property sector is also sougth after, with Japanese companies that have invested heavily in the United States in recent years turning their attention to undervalued real estate, particularly in the tourism field.
Analysts pointed to the recent sale of Sydney's five-star Regent Hotel to Japanese interests for more than 145 mnl dlrs as indicative of the type of property being sought.
"They think they find good value real estate here which, with long term and fixed capital investment, is the kind of investment Australia needs", Buttrose added.
Kuwait's iol-reliant and debt-ridden economy has started to pull out of a nosedive but oil prices will determine the pace of recovery, bankers and economists say.
Crucial iwll be the ability of the 13-member OPEC to hold oil prices around a new benchmark of 18 dlrs a barrel in the northern hemisphere summer when demand usually slackens.
Bankers setimate the economy, measured in terms of gross domestic product (gdp), shrank 19 pct in real terms last year after contracting 8.1 pct the year before.
This was after taking into account inflation in consumer prices of 1.5 pct in 1985, sloiwng to 1.0 pct in 1986.

Factors depressing economic activity include the 6-1/2-year-old Iran-Iraq war on Kuwait's doorstep, which threatens the emirates' vital oil export lifeline through the Gulf and has sapped business confidence.

But sentiment received a much-needed boost in September when, after a series of piecemeal steps to combat a debt crisis caused by the 1982 crash of local stock market, a comprehnesive new debt settlement program was introduced.
The share crash, result of a speculative spree in forward trading, left 95 billion dlrs fo post-dated cheques in default.
The cheques were also used as collateral for consumer spending, thus generating an informal credit sysetm.
Much of the debt has been watered down but big sums are still owed by individuals and companies.
There was some 4.4 billion dinars (about 15.7 billion dlrs) ni outstanding bank credit at the end of 1986, of which one-quarter to one-third was estimated by bankers to rank as bad or doubtful debt.
But the goevrnment has repeatedly said it will not allow any banks to go under.
The new debt settlement scheme etnails a rescheduling of problem credit over 10 to 15 years, depending on whether debtors have regular cash flows or not.

Banks' shareholders and depositors will have their rights guaranteed by hte government -- an edict of vital significance in a country of only 1.7 mln people where the financial sector is the biggest after oil.
Kuwait is better placde than any other OPEC country to ride out the oil glut, bankers and economists say.
Kuwait has an OPEC quota of 948,000 barrels per day (bpd) compared with production capacity of 4.0 mln bpd mentioned last eyar by Oil Minister Sheikh Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah.

But strategic diversification into downstream operations ni Europe several years ago and a hefty refining investment at home gives it guaranteed markets abroad and enables it to sell over one-half of its output as high-grade refined oil products.
Oil industry sources say Kuwait is bale to get an average 2.00 dlrs a barrel more by selling oil in the form of processed product such as gas oil, kerosene and naphtha, rather than as crude.
Bankers say the rebound in oil priecs is the major reason for cautious optimism.
Other reasons are low domestic inflation, a bottoming out of the fall in improts in recent years and signs government spending on productive sectors will remain steady.
External accounts are in good shape, with an estimated 1.8 billion dinar current accuont surplus in 1986, 16 pct below that for 1985, but still an achievement in the recession-hit Gulf.
Kuwait's petrodollar reserves in mid-1986 were put officially at over 80 billion dlrs, earning investment income of the equivalent of aobut 3.65 billion dlrs a year.
But for the first time since the end of the oil boom, these resreves may not be enough to prevent a "real" budget deficit for the 1986/87 fiscal year ending June 30, bankers say.
In a budget portrayed by bankers as mildly contractionary, revenues for 1986/87 were cut 38.6 pct and spending 11 pct, doulbing the nominal deficit to 1.33 billion dinars.
This left out income from state reserves, usually excluded in official budget accounting, which are forecast by bankers at up ot 1.0 billion dinars in 1986/87, resulting in some shortfall.
Bankers say it is too early ot venture a forecast for economic growth this year or next.
"It depends on oil prices," noe said.
"This smumer is important."
Cabinet Affairs Minister Rashid al-Rashid said lsat Sunday the cabinet has ratified recommendations to rationalise state spending in favour of productive sectors and reactivate the economy.
He gave no details but bankers asy these are expected to be spelled out in the 1987/88 budget, possibly in June.
Malaysia is unlikely to meet its targetde output of five mln tonnes of oil palm in calendar 1987, oil palm growers told Reuters.
Output in 1987 is expected to reach around 4.5 mln tonnes, unchanged from 1986, because of drought, low ues of fertiliser and overstressed palms, they said.
The growers were asked for their reaction to an Oil World newsletter report that Malaysia's oil palm output si likely to drop sharply this year.

Palm oil now sells at around 700 ringgit a tonne, or about 115 ringgit less than soybean oil, but Malaysia must sell more palm oil to prevent a stock buildup that could damage the industry, a leading growre told Reuters.
The country's palm oil stocks now total some 500,000 tonnes against about 800,000 last Marc,h the growers said.
The growers expect palm oil prices to ease later this year due to pressure from South American and U..S
The current South American oilseed harvest, mainly soybean, is likely to be around 25.7 mln tonnes against the prveious 21.7 mln tonne crop, they said.
In adidtion, new U.S.
Soybean plantings are also expected ot enter the market around November when Malaysian palm oil output peaks.

They said new planting of palms is also likely to slow, with some 50,000 hectares expected to be planted with new trees against 100,000 in 1986, although the effects of this reduction will not be felt for abotu another three years.

Elders IXL Ltd <ELXA.S> plans to float off the around 5,000 public houses belonging ot its U.K. Subsidiary Courage Ltd to raise about one billion stg, Elders strategy executive director Stuart Kelso said.

Drinks industry yb acquiring Allied-Lyons Plc <ALLD.L>.

iMnistry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) Vice Minister Makoto Kuroda leaves for Washington today with data he hopes will refute U.S. Charges Japan has violated a pact on microchip trade.

A three-man Japanese trade team is already in Washington laying the groundwork for talks between Kuroda and Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Michael Smith aimed ta persuading the U.S. Not to impose tariffs on certain Japanese products.
But Kuroda said he is taking on new proposals.
"I have nothing in my briefcase except an explanation of the current situatoin," Kuroda told the daily newspaper Asahi Shimbun.
Kuroda said the U.S. Decision was based on incorrect data and an exaggearted sense of MITI's power to control market forces.
"The U.S. Has excessvie expectations.
To stabilise supply-demand relations which have been disrupted by excess inventories since 1958 will take some time," he said.

Norway will from June require finance institutions and insurance companies to report lending volume ot the central bank once a month rather than quarterly in a bid to tighten domestic lending, Finance Ministry officials said.
Norwegian Bank Association President Trond Reinertsen told Rueters the new rule would make it more difficult for banks to transfer funds to financial and insurance companies for lending.

Banks have in the past used the two month lapse in loan registration to transfer money for lending to finance and insurance groups to avoid penalty reserve requirements for lending in excess fo government set ceilings.
The new rule brings loan reporting requirements for insurance and finance companies in line with those alreday applied to commercial banks, Ministry officials said.
Borrowers have increasingly sought loans from finance and insurance companies after the central bank last year clamepd down on what it called excessive bank lending.
Bank lending dropped by five billion crowns in January from 260 billion crowns the previous month ni response to the stricter penalty reserve requirements, Oslo bankers said.
They said recent central bank cuts in the overnight rate it charges bansk might offset new pressure on interest rates.

Negotiations between mining companies and the National Union of Mineworkers are foundering adn mines could face a May Day work stoppage, the Chamber of Mines said.

tI said the union accepted all the proposals except giving advance notification for May 1.
tI said miners had been offered a full paid holiday on May 1 or a premium of six pct of their basic monthly pay for working that day.

Nippon Steel Corp <NSTC.T> denied local newspaper reports that China has been seeking to buy steel plants from Japanese firms which plan to suspend output unedr the recently announced rationalisation program.

Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd <JARD.HK> said it will withdraw the previously announced four-for-one bonus issue of "B" shares and replcae it by a two-for-five bonus issue of ordinary shares.

A top U.S. Official said Japan ahs little chance of persuading the U.S. to drop threatened trade sanctions, despite the efforts of a Japanese team that left for Washington today.

Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was asked at a press conference whether Japan's moves to boost its domestic economy and oepn its markets could persuade the U.S. Not to impose tariffs on Japanese imports said, and replied: "...It is probably too early for the figures to demonstrate that the situation has turned around and to permit the result you have described."
Armacost said the U.S. Hopes Japan will take steps to lift its domestic economy and reduce dependence on exports, remoev barriers to imports and settle outstanding trade issues.

"There are obvious problems at the moment in the trade area, but we do nto wish those problems to divert attention from important areas of cooperation that continue to exist on security and political issues," he said.

"The question is whether through cooperative actions between our governments we can reduce the (trade) imbalance or whether Congress takse action to reduce it through protectionist legislation," he said.

Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky said today Moscow felt "indignation and regert" at what he called "truly hostile statements about the Soviet Union" made by President Reagan.

A bid by San Miguel Corp (SMC) <SANM.MN> to buy back 38.1 mln sequestered shares from United Coconut Planters Bank (UCPB) has been hit by two new lawsuits, soucres in the Philippine food and brewery company said.

A Manila court yesterday issued an injunction barring UCPB from selling the shares, which represent 31 pct of SMC's outstanding capital stock of 121 mln shares, until hearings no April 21 on a petition filed by Eduardo Cojuangco, a former chairman of both SMC and UCPB.
Cojuangco said the Coconut Industry Investment Fund (CIIF) and 1.4 mln farmers were the rightflu owners of the shares.
Cojuangco said the shares were held ni trust by UCPB and represented a blue chip investment.
His petition said UCPB's plans to slel the shares to SMC were "a serious breach of fiduciary duties."

The SMC sources said the proposed share sale could also be held up yb a second derivative suit filed before the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) by Eduardo de los Angeles, a government nominee on the company's board.
De los Angeles, who represents SMC's minority stockholders, asked the SEC to block the transaction, approved last week by the comapny's board.
On April 2 the board sanctioned the repurchase of the sequestered shares for 4.79 billion pesos at 126 pesos per shar.e
De los Angeles told the SEC the company's retained earnings of 1.33 billion pesos would be wiped out by the purhcase of the shares and would prevent the declaration of dividends.
De los Angeles said the sahre purchase would also violate an SMC agreement with its creditors to maintain a 2.2-to-1 debt to equity ratio.
He quoted SMC's chief financial dierctor Ramon del Rosario as telling the board that the transaction would boost the ratio to 2.5-to-1.
In petitioning the SEC, de ols Angeles amended an earlier suit two weeks ago in which he charged SMC Chairman Andres Soriano III and nine other directors of violating their duties.
De los Angeles' earlier complaint related to SMC assuming last December a 26.5 mln drl loan contracted by SMC's Hong Kong subsidiary <Neptunia Corp> for a down payment on the shares.
The loan assumption was again ratified by lats week's board meeting.
An arbitration panel set up by President Corazon Aquino to resolve the ownership issue si expected to submit its report by April 15.

"The amended suit filed by Eduardo de los Angeles is part of a continuing attempt by certain elements, in complete disregard of the facts and with questionable motives, to delay an early dispositoin of the sequestered shares," San Miguel Corp said in a statement.

"Coming as it does, when San Miguel Corp and UCPB have reached agreement on the price of the shares and the method of payment, this suit is in direct contravention of the governmetn's expressed desire to reach an amicable settlement of the controversy by April 15," the statement added.
A San Miguel spokesman said he had on comment on Cojuangco's court petition, adding: "Any statement coming from us might be interpreted as adversarial."

Meanwhile, Ramon Diaz, the head of a government panel which sequestered the shares last year, siad Soriano was not eligible to buy the major portion of the shares because he was a United States citizen.

Nickel rpices are unlikely to rise significantly from current levels unless further steps are taken to reduce production, Shearson Lehman Brothers said in its quarterly nickel market report.

Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said a weaker dollar would be risky and a further appreciation of the mark would damage prospecst for sustained West German economic growth.

In a speech to the Institute of Contempory German Affairs here, Poehl said "It would be an extremely risky policy to aim for a further substatnial decline in the value of the dollar to correct the trade deficit."
He said the United States could face a vicious circle of depreciation, inflatoin and more depreciation if it took that route.
Poehl noted West Germany had already takne steps to meet U.S.
Demands for greater stimulation of its domestic economy, accelerating tax cuts, cutting interets rates and tolerating above-target money supply growth.

He said he would have been ahppy to have brought forward five billion marks of tax cuts now planned for January 1988 to the beginning of this year, but he said the government faced political constraints getting such measures through the upper house of the West German parliament.
But there were laso limits to the impact West Germany could accept on exports from a rising mark, he said.
Poehl said West eGrmany relied on exports for about one-third of its gross national product, so a substantial erosion of export markets could not be offset by increasing demand at home.
"A further appreciation of the mark coudl even be an obstacle to further growth," he said.

Poehl said the Bundesbank had tolerated rapid money supply growth last year because the country enjoyed low inflation and because external factors, including low oil prices and favourable terms of trade, had given some extra leewya.
But Poehl said West Germany now faced a difficult dilemma over monetary policy.
The underlying rate of inflation aws now two pct, not the reported negative inflation rates last year, and West Germany was affected more than before by exchange rate developments.
"For the time being, we wlil have to focus our policy more on the external side, and we can live with a more expansionary money supply.
But we msut be very careful," he said.
He said he shared some fo the U.S. Concern about Japan's trade surpluses, which affected European countries as well as the United States.

Poehl welcomed the so-called Louvre accord of monetary officials of major industrialized countries, saying the importance of the February 22 agreement to stabilize exchange rates had been underestimated.
All partners had agreed that the dollar was at about the right level, and that further changes would damaeg growth, he said.
"This wsa a remarkable change in attitude, especially on the part of our American colleagues," he said.
But eh said there was still a danger that the correction of the dollar's value could overshoot.

Japan should promote division of labour with its Asian neighbours, especially the newly industrialized countries, to help achieve more balanced world economic growth, teh Bank of Japan said in a report.

Instead of trying to rpoduce everything by itself, Japan should open up its market further to imports, transfer manufacturing facilities abroad and increase technology transfer with those nations, the bank said in its monthly report.
Japan should ont see industrializing Asian nations as mere competitors in its overseas and domestic markets but as countries that can contribute to the region's prosperity.

The bank said trade rleations between Japan and the Asian neighbouring countries have so far been vertical, meaning that Japan imports primary goods from those countries and exports manufactured goods to them.
But htis has resulted in an increase in their trade deficits with Japan while some newly industrialized Asian nations have accumulated trade surpluses with countries like the United States.

California regulators said they were seeking disciplinary action against hte accounting firm KMG Main Hurdman as the result of a 1985 audit of Technical Equities Corp., an investment firm that filed for bankruptcy last year.

A sharp oil price edcline and sharp fluctuations of exchange and interest rates in 1986 produced a mixed economic performance by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), a United Nations study said.

The annual report of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) said the international economic environment reversed the fortunes of teh trade-oriented economies of the six ASEAN member countries.
It said the already low 1985 growth rates of ASEAN's oil exporting countries -- Brunei, Malaysia and Indonesia -- dropped furthre after the oil price fall.
Three oil importers -- Singapore, the Philippines and Thailand -- improved their performanec mainly by restructuring their economies.
But the report said the oil price fall reduced export earnings, worsening economic prospects fro the exporters.
The exporters' non-oil commodity prices did not show major improvement and protectionist pressures from industrial countries restricted export fo manufactured products, it said.
The GDPs of Indonesia, which was 1.9 pct in 1985, and Malaysia, which fell a real one pct, bareyl grew in 1986.

The two countries, buffeted by unfavourable external factors in the past few years, were forced to curb aggregate domestic consumption demands last year to avoid severe balance of payments pressures and to resotr to extensive commercial borrowings.
Body said the economic outlooks of Singapore, Thailand and the Philippines improved steadily in 1986 as teh year advanced.

It said the most favourable factor benefiting the three was the realignment of key currencies, especially the appreciation of teh yen, which has resulted in the increased competitiveness of their exports against those from Japan.
The report said the downward spiral plaguing the Philippine economy since 1983 was reversed into an estimated 0.9 pct GPD growth in 1986 with agriculture and public utilities becoming growth sectors.
It said the resumption of hte Philippines' sustained growth rests largely on a satisfactory solution of its debt problem.
ESCAP said the yen appreciation, toegther with economic restructuring measures, played a big role in helping Singapore recover faster than expected from its 1.8 pct GDP decline in 1985.
It said the Singapore GDP achieved a growth of over one ptc last year after registering positive growth from the second quarter.

The Singapore economic revival was hampered by its own adjustment measures especially its two-year wage freeze enforced last April, a glut of its propetry market and depressed conditions in its ASEAN neighbours which hurt Singapore because they take about a quarter of its total exports.
The report said Thailand benefited from hte changing world economic environment far more than any of its ASEAN neighbours.

The Thai performance stemmed from the expansion o its non-traditional export items lsat year to cover more manufactured products and its greater exploration of unsaturated export markets such as Asia, the Middle East and the European Community.
Britain and Japan clashed todya over U.K.
Demands for greater access to the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) as trdae tensions between the two countries mounted.

British consumer affairs minister Michael Howard told reporters he was dissatisfied with teh exchange's response to Britain's non-negotiable timetable for increased British membership and warned of possible reprisals in the future.
He described his meeting with Tokyo stock exchange (TSE) head Michio Takeuchi, ni which he demanded greater exchange access, as "very frank indeed."
In a separate press conference, TSE President Michio Takeuchi said the exchange hsa done its utmost to liberalise its membership and called on Britain to make some concessions.
According to Takeuchi, Howard wants three British firms to be naemd members of the Tokyo stock exchange by the end of this year.
Neither Takeuchi nor Howard would naem the companies.
"Next May is the earliest possible date for opening our membesrhip and I want the British government to understand this," Takeuchi said.
Membership cannot be increased before space on the trading floor is expanedd in May 1988, he said.
Howard told reporters that was not good enough and said that Brtiain would use its powers to ban Japanese financial institutions from London if it was not satisfied with Tokyo.
Japan has until the next meeting of senior officials from the two countries in May or June to come up with a potsive response to the British timetable or face retaliation, he said.
"The timetable was constructed ni a way that made it a very reasonable request and I expect it to be met," he said.

Asked about the exchange's argument that it has no folor space to expand membership, Howard replied, "We find it very difficult in our country to understand why the considerable ingenuity and resourcefulness of the Japanese (in world markets) is unable to overcome problems of that kind."

While here, Howard said he also expressed frustration with the huge trade imbalance with Japan and with Tokyo's handling of demands by Britain's Cable and Wireless for a greater roel in Japan's telecommunications business.
According to Japanese newspaper reports, at least soem of that message may have penetrated.

China's foreign debt is very low given its export capability, the size of its economy nad its growth potential and the country is politically stable, Jean-Maxime Leveque, chairman of Credit Lyonnais, told reporters.

Dollars and elss yen, Leveque said he had not offered any advice, but added: "The yen and the dollar are not stable, but the ECU is stable."

The policies fo the open door and economic development outlined in 1979 will not change, although there may be fluctuations in speed."

Australian trade unions said they have launched week-long strikes and other industrial action in New South Wales, NSW, to protest against new laws that would reduce injury cmopensation payments.

The Tanzanian government raised the price of eber, soft drinks and cigarettes by 20 pct and telephone and telex calls by 10 pct in an attempt to keep its budget deficit for this financial year roughly on target.

Banking supervisory authorities are not carrying out any special checks at banks in hte wake of the currency fraud scandal at Volkswagen AG <VOWG.F>, a spokesman for the Hesse regional state central bank, LZB, said.
But inspectors are paying particular attention ot foreign exchange matters in their routine checks at banks, he said in answer to enquiries.
hTere is no evidence rules were broken.

The LZB spokesman was commenting on rpess reports that banks had "parked" open currency positions for short periods with VW to circumvent regulations limiting the size of open currency positions that can be carried by banks overnight.
The press allegations meerged after VW said it may have lost 480 mln marks as a result of a possible currency fraud.
LZBs are regional branchse of the Bundesbank.
Their inspectors also act for the Federal Banking Supervisory Office in West Beriln, which regulates banking in West Germany.
Following the 1974 Herstatt bnak crash on currency speculation, West Germany limited a bank's total open positions overnight to 30 pct of shareholders' equity and reserves.
German press reports have sadi some banks circumvented this rule by selling excess positions to VW, then repurchasing them.
The banking regulations onyl cover banks.
Company foreign exhcange activities are not subject to the banking regulators.
The LZB spokesman said there were no concrete signs that hte regulations had been broken, and it would be irresponsible to instigate a special check just on the basis of the reports.
The LZBs receive monthly balance sehet statistics from banks in their areas, which they check, and they also routinely inspect all banks in greater detail over longer periods.
But LZB officials said it would be hard for inspectors to detect a breach of these rules as they do not check companies and therefore would not see both sides of any parking deal.
"If the managements of the banks have not spotted them, it will be evne harder for our inspectors," said one official.
It would be up to the public prosecutors to order special checks on suspicoin of breaches of these regulations, they said.
Prosecutors in Brunswick are already investigating the VW currency scandal, and have ordered teh arrest of VW's former chief foreign exchange dealer.
Breaches of the Banking Law in this way can be punished by a 100,000 mrak fine for the dealers involved, and in extreme cases by removal of the managers if their active involvement is proved.

Senate Banking Committee Chairman William Prxomire (D-Wis) said he planned to introduce legislation shortly to require greater public disclosure of corporate takeovers and fairer treatment for all shareholders.
Speaking to the National Association of Manufacturers, Proxmire said recent insider trading stock scandals increased the chanec that Congress will act to curb abuses.
"We are proposing legislation that would provide for more disclosure, would be fairer to all shareholders, adn would insure that takeovers are properly financed," he said.

Among the provisions, the bill would reduce the threshold for notifying the Securities and Exchange Commission that a investor or group has acquired a percentage of stock in a company to three ptc from the current five pct threshold within 10 days, Proxmire said.
In addition, there would be a pre-notificaton requirement that an investor intended to aquire three pct thta would have to filed with the SEC.
Proxmire said the pre-notification requirement was meant to prevent arbitragers from having a jump on the general public in knowing aobut coming takeover attempts.
Proxmire said he would call for extending the period that a tender offer must be kept open under the Williams Atc to 60 business days from the current 20 business days.
His bill would provide fro private suits if the acquiring company violated the time period on the tender offer.
To correct abuses in the financing of takeovers, Proxmire said the legislation would aim at insuring current margin requirments are prpoerly enforced.
The Federal Reserve Board has a 50 pct magrin requirement for purchasing stock, but Proxmire said it is not generally enforced in hostile takeovers.
Rather, the groups or individuals leading a takeover declare that they can raise the capital for a takeover without actually puttign any of their own money, Proxmire said.
He said his bill would allow private suits for damages for failure to meet the Federal Reserve's 50 pct margin requiremenst.
The bill also would require more disclose wehn several investors form an alliance in a hostile takeover.
"When Pickens and Icahn get together we watn people to know about it," Proxmire said.
Proxmire said he favored the approach used in Britain towards two-tiered tender offers that insrues that all shareholders recieve equal treatment.
He said he expected amendments to the bill also would cover defensive mechanisms such sa green mail and poison pills.
Proxmire said he intended to introduce his bill later this month and predicted the Sentae committee would act this spring.
He said he was hopeful Congress could pass a bill this year.

Bankers Trust New York Corp said it has placed its approximately 540 mln dlrs of medium- and long-term loans to Brazil on non-accrual status and that first-quarter net incmoe will be reduced by about seven mln dlrs as a result.
Brazil suspended interest payments on its 68 billion dlrs of medium- and long-term debt no February 22.

U.S. banking regulations do not require banks to stop accruing interest on loans until payments are 90 days overdue, but Bankers Trust said it acted now because of "teh high potential of a continued suspension that would result in reaching the 90-day limit in the second quarter of 1987."
Assuming no cash payments at crurent interest rates are received for the rest of 1987, Bankers Trust estimated that full-year net income would be reduced by about 30 mln dlrs.
Bankers Trust said it assumes taht debt negotiations between Brazil and its commercial bank lenders will lead to the resumption of interest payments.
The negotiations resume in New York on Friday when central bnak governor Francisco Gros is expected to ask banks for a 90-day rollover of some 9.5 billion dlrs of term debt that matures on April 15.

West German Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said today's meetings of maojr industrial countries would look at ways of strengthening the Paris accord on stabilizing foreign exchange rates.
Stoltenberg told journalists he saw no fundamental weakness of the February 22 agreement fo the Group of Five countries and Canada to keep exchange rates near the then-current levels.
But he declined to say what measures would be discussed ahead of a communique of the Gropu of Seven ministers later today.
Stoltenberg and Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said the importance of the Paris agreement, also known sa the Louvre accord, had been underestimated.

Stoltenberg said there is greater agreement now among major countries than six months ago, at the time of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, marked by sharp discodr between the United States and its major trading partners.
"There is no fundamental weakness of the Parsi accord," he said.
"We will be looking at ways of strengthening it, but I do not want to disucss that here.
Stoltenberg said the Louvre agreement was working despite a "slight firming" of the yen against teh dollar.
And Poehl noted that the dollar/mark parity was unchanged since February 22 without the Bundesbank havnig had to sell marks to support the dollar.
T"he Louvre agreement has been honored by the market," he said.
Poehl said West Germany had lived up to its side of the bargain in Paris by preparing the way for tax cuts to be accelerated as a way of tsimulating growth.
Poehl said, hoewver, that Japan had not yet fulfilled its pledges for economic stimulation.
"And we will have to see if the United Sattes is able to do what they promised in Paris on reducing the budget deficit -- and get it through Congress," he added.
Stoltenberg reiterated West eGrman concern about a further fall in the dollar, noting that the mark was up 85 pct against the dollar and nearly 20 pct on a trade-weighted basis.
"You acnnot expect that to go unnoticed in an economy.
And ti is not just a German problem, it is a European problem," he said.

Compaq Computer Corp, IBM's chief rival in the personal computer market, scored a big gain on Wall Street toda.y
Compaq's stock rose 1-3/8 to 32-1/4 on volume of 13. mln shares.
"The rationale for the move," one trader said, "is that the damage from the IBM announcement yesterday was elss than expected."
He said Compaq's stock had been under pressure recently because of anticipation of IBM's unveiling of a new ilne of personal computers.

But analysts said the new computers, though they do contain a lot of proprietary concepts, will not be sa hard to copy as some other PC makers had feared.

"The long range issue ehre is who wins and who loses in the PC business, and that issue was not resolved yesterday and is unlikely to be decided any time soon," analyst Mark Stahlman of Sanford C. Bernstein and Co said.
Stahlman raeffirmed his recommendation of Compaq and Apple Computer Inc <AAPL>.
Stahlman said T"he critical investment question now is who will have a pickup in sales in the near term.
We expect ot see a strong demand setting for PCs for the rest of this year, and that will boost the revenues for all of the major PC vendors."
"The first quarter was the strongest PC sales period no record for Compaq, Apple and IBM," Stahlman said, "and I don't think the IBM announcement is going to change that trend soon."
"In anticipating the IBM anonuncement, Compaq has made pricing adjustments necessary to compete for its immediate purposes," he said.

European options exchanges will see spectacular growth over the next five years as more professional investosr discover the options markets, Bernard Reed, manager of the London options exchange said.

"But the dominance by the professionals should nto make us neglect private clients," he noted.
"Successful exploitation of retail business has been oen of the keys to success."
Reed said derived option products in particular will become a popular instrument for managing equity rissk.

Dutch Stock Index Fund options to be relaunched on May 18 and the upcoming options no London's FTSE 100 index will see a 30 pct yearly turnover growth until 1990, Reed estimated.

The CBOE and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have agreed with Morgan Stanley to trade options adn futures on the capital international EAFE index which will let investors participate in worldwide market moves.

The U.K. Government hopes for a breakthrough on the deadlock with Japan ovre trade policies during next week's visit to Tokyo by Corporate Affairs Minister Michael Howard, political sources said.
Howard, who leaves for Japan tomorrow, told Reuters he will try to proomte understanding on trade issues during his visit.

Meanwhile, Britain will re-examine a letter from Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone proimsing personal help in solving the row over a U.K. Firm's bid to win a significant role in Japan's telecommunications market, government sources said.
Tensions have risen following Britain's deicsion to arm itself early with new statutory powers which it says could be used against certain Japanese financial institutions.

Britain reacted optimistically at first to the letter from Nakasone ot Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, seeing it as a signal that he would work towards ensuring a satisfactory outcome to the bid launched by Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L>, government officials said.
But this view has since been clouded by reports from Tokyo that Nakasone's assurances really constituted little more than politeness in the face of British anger, they added.
Howard said he would use his trip to push for a bigger role in Japan's telecommunications industry for Cable and Wireless Plc.
The U.K. Government has made the issue a test case for Japans' willingness to open its markets adequately to outside competition.

Asked whether the letter from Nakasone was a reejction of attempts by Britain to achieve that, Howard said "I am not sure it is correct to regard Mr Nakasone's letter as a rejection of Mrs Thatcher's request of him - and it says he is taking a personal interest in this problem.
"I don't understand it to be closde at all."

Howard added that during his Tokyo visit he would be "talking to them about it (the letter), finding out exactly what they do mean about it, and making it plain that we take a very serious view of the fact that access to Japanese markets is not as free as we allow access to our markets to be."

He noted that under the new Financial Services Act, Britain could revoke or deny licences to Japanese banking and insurance institutions in London if U..K Firms fail to receive similar treatment in financial markets in Japan soon.
"I hope it won't come to that, and I don't thikn it will," Howard added.
During the trip Howard will meet officials in the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Ministry of Finance, the Trade Ministry, and Posts and Telecommunications Minister Shunjiro Karasawa.
Karasawa is regarded as behind opopsition to any significant role for Cable and Wireless in the Japanese telecommunications industry.
Share prices on the London Sotck Exchange were undermined again today by fears of a possible U.K./Japanese trade war.
This was despite denials by Tarde and Industry Secretary Paul Channon that Britain was on the verge of a trade war.
He otld a meeting of insurance brokers today that Britain believed a "sensible solution" could be found which would open Japanese markets to British goods.

Government officials were ta pains today to deny that Britain had set a deadline of three weeks for Japan to promise similar access to its financial markets to U.K.-based financial firms as that enjoyed in London by equivalent Japanese firms.

They said that Department of Trade and Industry officials had said yesterday that the measures against Japaense financial institutions could be imposed from then but that this did not necessarily constitute a deadline.
Experts believe Britain would loes out by acting against Japanese banks, insurance and investment institutions.
But despite the danger of Japanese firms taking thier trade elsewhere in Europe, Howard said he did not expect the move to backfire.
He said in a radio interview today "it si true that we benefit from their presence - but they would not want to lose those advantages.
And I am sure they are making their viwes plain to the Japanese government on this matter."
Howard, who will also be visiting South Korea before returning to London on April 11, said his trip to Tokyo was planned well before the curretn trade row.
Howard said his atlks with Japanese officials would also include ways of jointly combating financial fraud in global markets with Japanese officials.
This owuld be done through a cooperation between national regulatory bodies.
He said a memorandum of understanding for ecxhanging information to combat financial fraud would be sought with Japan on terms similar to one signed last autumn between Britain and the United States.

U.S. and Japanese officials meet tomorrow to try to settle a dispute over semiconductor trade and to cut short the 300 mln dlr penalty tarfifs President Reagan has ordered imposed on Japanese exports.

The Customs Bureau last week started to levy a bond on the Japanees goods that Reagan ordered penalized.

Britain's Export Credits Guarantee Deaprtment (ECGD) is holding talks with Nigeria aimed at resuming insurance cover for British exporters to Nigeria, the head of ECGD's international debt division, Gerry Breach, said.
The ECGD suspended cover no Nigeria in 1984 after the country fell into arrears on payments of insured and uninsured debts.
Following last week's bilateral accord between Britain and Nigeria to reschedule the country's insured trade debts, bankers had hoped that talks woudl commence on a resumption of cover.
Breach made his comments in an address to a private meeting of businessmen, a copy of which was made available to teh press.
Breach noted that for hte ECGD to consider "a gradual introduction of a package of new support" certain criteria would have to be met.

This would involve the Nigerian economic structural adjustment porgram being put into effect and being endorsed by the International Monetary Fund, the program remaining on course and continuing to be endorsed by the IMF and a satisfactory level of acceptance by the Nigerian government of the ECGD insured short-term trade arrears.

Breach said that these criteria are now beginning ot be satisfied, adding that while the ECGD could not yet formally announce new cover, it was holding discussions with Nigeria on priorities for new credits.

He said an announcement would be made "as soon as possible" on an agreement and the ECGD would create a packaeg for Nigeria that would include the department's normal range of export trade support facilities.
British exports to Nigeria exceeded 505 mln stg in 1986.
Breach noted that since cover was removed, the ECGD has maintained a limited amount of short-term trade cover for Nigeria, whcih was backed by letters of credit from the Nigerian Central Bank.

While the ECGD would initially continue to use this structure under a new package, it would also hope to expand teh volume of coverage in the short-term area and relax the terms it is prepared to underwrite towards the commonly accepted maximum of 180 days.

World Bank President Barber Conable expressed concern that trade protectionism, at the heart of a new showdown between teh United States and Japan, might spread throughout the industrial world.

But in an interview with Reuters, Conable said the action by the United States to slap tariffs on certain electronic goods from Japan did not mean the countries were heading fro a full-scale trade war.
Conable said the World Bank has been pressing developing countries to open their markets, arguing that a free tradnig environment increased the possibility of global economic growth.

"We have, in fact, been making adjustment loans to many countries in the developing world which have encouraged the opening of their markets and we want to be sure that the developed world doesn't close at teh same time," he said.
He said the U.S. action against Japan was "a significant retalaitory step but it did not constitute a basic change in trade policy."
The interview came just before next week's semi-annual meetings of teh Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Referring to Brazil's recent interest payments moratorium, Conable also said teh global debt situation was very serious and must be closely watched.

He said the Bank, which in the past has concentrated on making loans that assist the basic underpinnings in the develpoing world such as dams, roads and sewers, will increasingly make assistance available for economic reform.

The Bank has increased these loans, in part because of the debt crisis that has found countries desperately in need of new funds fro balance of payments adjustment and economic reforms aimed at opening their markets, encouraging foreign investment and reducing government's role in the economy.
"We're comfortable with adjustment lending, we expect, however, that it will neevr reach a majority of our portfolio," Conable said.
He made clear, however, that adjustment lending would continue to increase sa a proportion of overall Bank lending for some time.
He noted, "the problem of debt was a severe one and mayn countries are asking for adjustment assistance because of the problem of debt."
Conable, is a a former Republican Congressman from New York chosen by President Reagan for teh Bank position last year.

He is an associate of Treasury Secertary James Baker who launched the U.S. strategy for shoring up indebted nations in October, 1985 which included a call for increased adjustment lending by teh World Bank.
Conable also said that he expected the result of a major study of the Bank's organiztaion to be completed in the next several weeks.

He said the decision to seek a reorganization was based, in part, on the fact that the Bank had come unedr fire from the poorest countries for not doing enough to help and from the richest countries because of inefficiency.
the reorganization is considered a major initiative by Conable, and si being closely-watched by the agency's 151 member-countries as an indication of his management style and priorities.
"I want to be sure this institution is viewed by thsoe who must support it as soundly constituted so that it will be permitted to grow," Conable said.
However, he said "I don't believe tehre is anything basically wrong with this institution and I don't believe it has to have any redefinition of its purpose."
He said, however, that it was appraent that the debt initiative proposed by Baker has given the Bank a central role in dealing with the debt crisis.

Conable added that cooperation between the Bank and its sister agency, the International Monteary Fund, was good and that he talked often with IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus on a variety of issues.

On a personal level, Conable said that he not feel a need to upt his personal stamp on the Bank noting that "I don't have a particular mission here except to be useful to the institution and to the process of development."
He added, "so I don't feel a great calling to personaliez the institution."

On the development needs of sub-Sahara Africa, Conable said that the Bank wsa constantly reviewing new ways for assisting the region, noting that half of the recently agreed financing of 12.4 billion dlrs for Bank's International Development Association was earmarked for Africa.
Leading industrial nations are expected to consider new forms of debt relief for the very poorest nations, like those in the Sub-Sahar,a during next week's meetings.

A five billion dlr credit facility ebing arranged for two units of British Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> attracted over 15 billion dlrs in syndication but will not be increased, Morgan Guaranty Ltd said on behalf of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co of New York, the arranger.

A steep drop in goods-producing jobs detracted from U.S. March non-farm payroll emplyoment and makes it unlikely that the Federal Reserve will tighten monetary policy to defend the dollar, economists said.
U.S. March non-farm payroll employment rose 164,000, less thna the gain of 220,000 to 290,000 the financial markets expected.
Manufacturing employment fell 25,000, compared with February's 50,000 gani, while March construction employment dropped 45,000 after being unchanged in February.

"The momentum of industrial activity is tapering off as we end the first quarter," said Stephen Roach of Mogran Stanley and Co Inc. "This sets the stage for more sluggish growth in the second and third quarters."
"The Fed will view thsi as a caution flag on the economy," he said.
"They will not ease sa long the dollar is weak, but clearly they can't tighten."

David Wyss of Data Resources Inc said that the downward revision in February non-farm payroll employment to 236,000 frmo 337,000 means that employment gains in the first quarter were weaker than expected.

While Wyss left his first-quarter forecast of real U.S. gross national product growth at 3.5 pct, he said the March jobs data suggetsed a downward revision in his second-quarter growth forecast to 2.5 pct from 2.8 pct.
Bill Sullivan of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc said the average monthly gani in non-farm jobs in the first quarter was only 237,000, compared with 254,000 in the fourth quarter of 1986.
"There's momentum in first quarter laobr force activity, but less than assumed," he said.
"Gains in goods-producing jobs were sudbued at best.
This rules out any possibilty of the Fde tightening for exchange-related purposes."
In March, the average workweek fell back to its January level of 34.8 hours frmo 35.0 hours in February.
Manufacturing hours also fell back to their January level, totalling 40.9 hours in March comparde with 41.2 hours in February.
The Commerce Department noted that loss of manufacturing jobs in March was concentrated in automoblie, electrical and electronic manufacturing.
Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities International said that a 13,000 decline in auto manufacturing employmnet accounted for nearly half of the total drop in manufacturing jobs.
Economists said that a build-up in auto inventories resulting from a steep drop in sales has finally caught up wiht the labor force and may point to slower growth ahead.
Most expect an increase in inventories of as much as five pct to offset a steep four to five ptc drop in final sales in the first-quarter GNP accounts.
Roach said he expects first quarter U.S. GNP to rise two pct, to be followed by a gain of 1.0-.15 pct at best in the second and third quarters.
He said the March drop in industrial activity "is a reasonable response in light of the inordinate contribution inventory accumulatoin made to GNP."
Economists said the employment dtaa also suggest weak gains in industrial production and personal income for March.
They expect only marginal gains, if not small declines, for these indicators, compared with a February increases of 0.5 pct in industrial prdouction and 0.9 pct in personal income.

Steve Slifer of Lehman Government Securities said the dorp in March construction employment may also signal a drop in March housing starts, which rose 2.6 pct in February to 1.851 million units at an annual rate from 1.804 million units in January.
The rate of unemployment flel to 6.6 pct, its lowest level since March 1980, from 6.7 pct in February.
uBt Wyss pointed out that this resulted from a drop in the labor force, which fell to 119.2 mln in March from 119.35 mln in February.
T"his just means that there were fewer people looking for work, so the drop in unemployment doesn't mean much," he said.

eH said the latest employment report will not concern the Fed because it does points to GNP growth in the first half of 2.5-3.0 pct, but "it does suggest they can't afford to tighten to quickly either."

The statistical factors used to smooth out seasonal fluctuations in the jobs data may have understated March labor force gains, just as seasonal factors probably overstated them in January and February, Slifer said, but are consistent iwth his forecast of 1.8 pct first quarter GNP growth.
Economic growth remains sluggish, but Silfer does not think that the Federal Open Market Committee changed policy at theri meeting this week.
"At some point they will be more inclined to ease", he said.
For the time being, however, the March employment report "increases the likelihood they won't tighten, regardless of the dlolar."

Several pharmaceutical companies, drawn in the 1970s ot the fast growing cosmetics industry, are no longer finding it fashionable to sell makeup.
"The fad right onw is to purify and concentrate on the most attractive business.
Right now that's hte drug business," said David Saks, an analyst with Morgan, Olmstead.
Yesterday, Eli Lilly and Co joined hte ranks of other drug companies by choosing to sell off its lower growth Elizabeth Arden cosmetics business.
"It's not that Elizabeth Arden si bad.
To some it may be their pride adn joy, but to Eli Lilly, it's a diversion of their management energies and financial resources from their gemstone, which is the drug business," Saks said.
"Ardne is a good company.
I'm usre it's going to be a hot property.
I'm sure people iwll be lining up to buy it," said Lynne Hyman, E.F. Hutton cosmetics analyst.
Analysts said the Arden business could command about 600 mln dlrs, and likely buyres would be interested in its well-known name and distribution channels.
Analysts said Avon Products Inc, a door-to-door makeup distributor, and the Japanese company Shiseiod Co of Tokyo, might be willing buyers.

Analysts said most of the changes of control in the cosmetics industry have bene determined for the time being.
"There's not much out there that has'nt changed hands or isn't relatively stable," said Hyman.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reminded corporate raiders and others tendering for the shares of companies that they must extend the period their offers aer open if key conditions are changed.

Specifically, the agency said those making tender offers for companies' stock must extend the offers if they decide to eliminate conditions requiring a minimum number of shares to be tendered in order fro the offers to be valid.
Tender offers typically include minimum shaer conditions.
As a result, a purchaser would not be bound to buy the shares that were tendered if the minimum level were not reache.d

In an interpretation of current rules, which officials said clarifies the SEC's present position, the agency said a tender offer must be extended if a minimum share condition is waived, even if the purchasre reserved the right to do so.
The interpretation makes clear that waiving a minimum share condition is a "material change" of the tender offer under U.S. securities law, SCE officials said.

The SEC has already asid that other specific material changes, such as changes in the percentage of securities being sought or the price being offered, made during the course of a tender offer require a 10-day extension of the offer.
The length of the etxension, which is aimed at giving shareholders an adequate chance to assess revisions of a tender offer, was not specified in cases where the minimum share conditions were waived.
SEC officials asid the length of the extension in such cases would depend on the facts and circumstances surrounding each case, but would generally be between five and 10 days.
The agency cited two ercent tender offers in which waivers of a minimum share conditios were tried on the last day of each offer, denying shareholders the chance to react to the new information.
Officials declined to identify the tow offers.
"If a bidder makes a material change near or at the end of its offer, it will have to extend the offer to permit adequtae dissemination," the SEC said.
Federal securities law requires that all tender offers remain open for ta least 20 business days.
Fox Broadcasting, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp Ltd, is set to launch tow prime time television shows this Sunday on what some have called the fourth television network.

The company, built around Murdoch's two billion dlr acquisition of seven television stations last year, marks the first network startup since 1948, when ABC, now owned by Captial Cities/ABC Inc <CCB>, hit the airwaves.
"I think our goal, more than anything else, is to provide an alternative ot the three networks," said Fox president Jamie Kellner.
Fox's debut comes when earnings at two of the three networks are under pressuer and network advertising dollars have been growing slowly.
"The barriers to entry are exceptionally high," industry analyts Peter Appert of C.J.
"Their (Fox) saving grace is that their parent hsa deep pockets."

The question television industry, advertising and Wall Street executives are asking is whether this new entry can lure advertisers from the big three: CBS Inc <CBS>, ABC, and NBC, a unit of Generla Electric Co <GE>.
Network advertising revenues rose to 8.6 billion dlrs in 1986 from 8.3 billion a year earlier, wiht NBC accounting for all of the gain.
Revenues at CBS and ABC declined, analysst noted.
"They (Fox) are cmopeting for the same pool of funds as the traditional networks," said Jon Mandel, associate media director at Grey Advertising Inc.
uBt James Mandelbaum, a Los Angeles-based entertainment attorney said, "If they have enough money, they have a good chance of making it work."
oFx president Jamie Kellner said the company expects to lose 30 to 50 mln dlrs this year on revenues of about 150 mln dlrs.
eH said it will take three to five years to turn a profit.
oT succeed, the company must also win over the young viewership it has targeted with an offbeat set of shows, two of which debut this Sunday, and another, next weekend.
hTe first Fox-produced program -- "The Late Show," featuring comedienne Joan Rivers -- was shown last fall on Fox's seven stations and close to 100 affiliates.
Although the hsow has dropped recently in ratings, it still has a captive young audience in the late night time slot, analysts said.
Sunday's prime-time shows include a situation comedy, "Married ... with Children," which Kellner describes as an alternative to the suger coated family shows on hte networks.
It is also airing "The Tracy Ullman Show," featuring the British comedienne, isnger and actress.
Fox has lined up 107 independent TV stations around the U.S. to urn the shows.
The networks have some 637 affiated sattions.
To make sure viewers get a chance to see the programs, the company is taking the unprecedneted step of airing them three times in the course of the evening.

"I believe if some of their shows were on the traditional networks, it would be extremely high-rated," Mandel said, who added that his firm has signed up several million dlrs in advertising fro the shows.
But some question whether Fox will really becmoe a fourth network.
Robert Adler, president of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau, said many cable shows are geared ot the audience Fox is attempting to win.
"There are already many alternatives out there ot the three networks," he said.
And at least one network is not yte ready to consider Fox the competition.
nA ABC spokesman said, "the schedule we've put together for this Sunday night ... has not taken Fox's programming schedule into account."
uBt analysts noted that the major networks are keeping a eye on the venture to see how it fares in the ratings and with its advertisers.
oFx also appears willing to take a long-term view.
Asked whethre the company will be looking at ratings after Sunday's debut, Kellner said, "the last thing I want to do is worry about ratings because that was the last thing Murdoch told me to do."

U.S. scientists said some tropical vegetable oils can be hazardous to consumers whose haelth is at risk because of high levels of saturated fat, lending weight to a campaign by the American Soybean Association (ASA) for labelling changes.

The scientists appeared to support an ASA charge, denied by Malaysian palm growers, that imported coconut, palm and palm kernel oils cotnain high levels of saturated fat and thus raise blood cholesterol and the risk of heart disease.

In a petition filed in January, the ASA asked the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to require palm, palm kernel adn coconut oils to be identified as saturated fats on food manufacturers' labels.
The FDA responded to the ASA in a letter saying ti would consider the petition as a comment to a proposed rule dealing with cholesterol and fatty acid labelling of foods.
Malaysian oil palm growers have said the charges by the AAS that palm oil consumption increases blood cholesterol and contributes to heart disease are untrue.
But Steve Chang, Professor of Food Science at Rutgers University, said, "Palm oil si definitely not good for human health because it has a high content of saturated fatty acid."
He added that the higher the fatyt acid, the greater the blood cholesterol level.
"It has been well established that high cholesterol levels will have a higher levle of heart disease," he said.

A Malaysian Oil Palm Growers Council official, Borge Bek-Nielsen, has said studies have shown that palm oil is cholesterol-free, low in saturated fats, has anti-cancer properties adn prevents blood clotting and blocking of arteries in humans.

Bek-Nielsen said Americans consume more saturated fats daily through food like butter, bacon, ham and beef than frmo palm oil, which, he added is rich in vitamins A and E. David Kritchevsky, Associate Director of the Wistar Institute in Philadelphia, appeared to take the ASA view on labelling.
"What people really have ot learn is to read labels," said Kritchevsky.
"The more a consumer knwos, the more likely he will make an intelligent choice."
The U.S. scientists said they had no doubt impotred palm, palm kernel and coconut oils contain high saturated fat levels.
Kritchevsky, a specialist in nutrition, said, "More saturated fat would rasie cholesterol levels...So, from that point of view it's a health risk.
High cholesterol levels in the blood are a risk factor for heart disease."

Susanne Harris, deputy assistant secretary of the U.S. Agriculture Department's Food and Consumer Services Division, said the health risk among consumers fo vegetable oils with high saturated fat levels was highest among those who have heart disease.
The scientists said more than 50 pct of the fatty acid content of the tropical oils was saturated, whereas less than 02 pct of the fatty acid content of soybean oil was saturated.

aDvid Ericksen, director of ASA's technical services, said U.S. soybean producers could regain about one-half of the 273 mln dlrs in sales lost to imported tropical oils if consumers were aware the vegetable oils were high in saturated fat.
mIported tropical oils displace 171 mln bushels of U.S. soybean sales in the U.S. market, ASA estimates.

"This is reflecting a tremendous maount of optimism on the part of the investment community that the outlook for the industry for the future is extremely attractive," Peters and Co Ltd oil analyst Wilf Gobert said.

Financial statements rfom Canada's major oil companies, culminating with Dome Petroleum Ltd's 2.20 billion Canadian dlr 1986 loss reported this week, painted a bleak picture of last year's results, analysts said.
"But hte financial statements are a snap shot and a recording of history.
The tsock market is the indication of the future," Gobert commented.
The Toronto tSock Exchange's oil and gas index of 41 companies is up to 4065.4 so far in trading today from 3053.15 at the end of 1986.
Among Canada's largest oil companies, class A shares fo Imperial Oil Ltd <IMO.A>, 70 pct owned by Exxon Corp <XON>, is trading at 71, up from a 52-week low of 34-3/4.
Shell Canada Ltd, 72 pct owned by Royal Dutc/hShell Group, is at 40-1/2, up from a low during the last year of 18-3/4.

Levesque Beaubien Inc oil analyst Robert lPexman forecasts operating profit for 10 of Canada's largest oil and gas companies will rise 37 pct in 1987 to about 1.44 billion dlrs and operating cash flow will increase 12 pct to 3.24 billion dlrs, based on an average oil price for the year of 16.50 U.S. dlrs a barrel.
"However, if prices ohld about 18 U.S. dlrs a barrel...1987 net operating income could show a 69 pct increase with cash flow 27 pct higher," analyst Plexman said.
"Although it is dfificult to forecast the extent of the profit improvement this year, the gain should be significant," he added.
Those improvements follow a sharp downturn ni 1986, when operating income for the ten companies dropped 47 pct to 1.05 billion dlrs and operating cash flow fell 22 pct to 2.90 billion dlrs.
But one industry soruce doesn't think oil prices will hold recent gains and more government assistance is needed.
Canadian Petroleum Association technical director Hans Maciej sees industry cash flow falling another 10 pct in 1987, after dipping about 60 pct last year.
Maciej said he sees crude oil supply outweighing demand and doesn't beileve a recent OPEC production accord will continue to support prices.
However, several companies share the optimsitic industry outlook expressed by a majority of analysts.
Shell Canada and <Norcen Energy Resources Ltd> forecast improved 1987 earnings ni their annual reports issued this week, assuming oil prices remain at or above 1986 levels.
"The industry's outlook for 1987 is positive, but not robust," Texaoc Canada said in its annual report.
"While iol prices have strengthened somewhat and there is good reason to believe that the general level is sustainable, continued volatility is likely," Texaco Canada added.
In hte face of short-term uncertainty, many companies have pared 1987 spending plans from last year's lower levels, deferring most frontier exploration work.
"The nidustry is becoming very selective in investments, very conservative and cautious, which is not unexpected," Canadian Petroleum Association's Maciej said.
Federal nad Alberta goverment aid measures helped cushion the industry downturn in 1986 and are improving 1987 results.
The most significant help cmae last September when the federal government lifted the 10 pct Petroleum Gas Revenue Tax (PGRT) 28 months earlier then planned.
Analysts estimate the tax rleief will save larger oil companies about 1.50 billion dlrs by the end of 1988.
The PGRT cut helped barke the steep profit and cash flow decline in 1986 for many oil companies and prevented further exploration spending cuts, analysts said.

"For a number of companies, the PGRT cut was aboslutely necessary to even maintain the kind of reduced investments that were made, otherwise the reduction would have been considerably more," Maciej said.

Rising demand for U.S. rice may gradually reduce surpluses while a marketing loan should help increase the U.S. share of the world rice market despite sluggish trade this year, the U..S Agriculture Department said.

In its quarterly rice outlook and situation summary, the department said U.S. rice use may surpass production during the 1986/87 marketing year, causing stocks ot fall about 10 mln hundredweight from a year earlier to an estimated 67 mln cwt on July 31.
Long grain acreage as a percentage of total acreage is expected to decilne this year, the report said.
USDA said factors once supportive of increaesd long grain acreage have turned around.

Domestic prices of medium grain relative to long grain have increased, the loan differential has been greatly reduced and increases in long grain yields relatiev to those of other classes have leveled off.
With the drop in domestic prices resulting from the marketing loan, domestic riec use is expected to grow at a faster rate, USDA said.
"Development of new products and increased promotion have helped make rice more available and visible to a widre range of consumers," USDA said.

USDA said world trade is expected to fall in 1987 because of large production and stocks but a weaker market should affect competing exporetrs more than the U.S. "The United States has already recovered a substantial share of the European Community market and made inroads into markets in the Middle East and Africa," the report said.

World rice consumption is projected to reach record levels in 1986/87, the report said, as higher per capita incomes, increased domestic production and low import prices have allowed people in mayn countries to substitute rice for coarse grains.
China, India and South Korea have increased output, while the Middle East and Africa have doubled imports since the mid-1970s, teh report said.

oFur U.S. meat processors have asked the federal government to relax a labelling requirement which they said discourages the use of mechanically separated meat, the U.S. Agriculture Department said.

The petition, filed by Bob Evans Farms, Odom Sausage Co, Sraa Lee Corp and Owens Country Sausage, asks USDA to allow mechanically separated meat to be listed on product labels as the species from which it was derived.
For example, "pork" would be litsed on the ingredients statement instead of "mechanically separated pork."

Under the petition, the calcium ocntent of the meat product would have to be stated on the label and the mechanically separated meat could constitute no more than 10 pct of the meat and poultry portion of the product.
Mechanically separated emat is a high-protein, low-cost product that has been approved for use since 1978, USDA said.

Current regulations allow use of mcehanically separated ingredients at levels up to 20 pct of the meat and poultry product, but require it to be listed in the ingredient statement as "mechanically separated (species)," USDA said.

USDA said the petitioning firms claimed companies avoid using mechanically separated meat ni their products because the term carries an "unwarranted negative connotation" in the minds of many consumers.
The petitioners also noted that no simliar regulation exists for poultry products.
Mechanically separated meat is made by placing carcass parts, which usually have been hand-trimmed but still have some remaining meat, into specialized procsesing equipment.

The Federal Open Market Committee at its February 10-11 meeting voted nine ot one to maintain the then-existing degree of reserve restraint, minutes showed.
The FOMC issued an asymmetric inter-meeting policy directive which gave graeter possibility to firmer rather than easier policy.
The Committee set a six to seven pct January through Macrh annualized growth target for M-2 and M-3 and no M-1 goal.
At the prior meeting in mid-December, the FOMC set a seevn pct target for M-2 and M-3 for November through March.
The February FOMC kept the four to eight pct Federal fudns rate "reference" range for policy, as in other recent meetings.
At a telephone conference on February 23, committee members discussed teh possible implications of the decisions reached in Paris for U.S. intervention in foreign exchange markets.
No conclusions weer contained in the minutes.

In its inter-meeting policy directive, the February FOMC said that "somewhat greater reserve restraint would, or slightly lesser reserve restraint mihgt, be acceptable depending on the behavior of the aggregates, taking into account the strength of the business expansion, developments in foreign exchange markets, progress against inflation, and conditions in domestic and international credit markets."
The February FOMC voted nine ot one for an unchanged policy.
Thomas Melzer, St Louis Federal Reesrve Bank president favored some tightening of reserve conditions.
He noted the strong growth in bank loans in November through January and the firm federal funsd rate that had prevailed despite the extraordinary pace of reserve growth.
He also cited the recent declines in the dolla'rs value.
Finally, looking ahead, Melzer pointed out the potential fro a further rise in inflationary expectations.
He believed that prompt restraints might avert the nede for more substantial tightening later.

Regarding inter-meeting policy adjustments, the FOMC minutes showed, "the members generally felt that policy implementation should eb especially alert to the potential need for some firming of reserve conditions."

In this view, the FOMC said somewhat greater reserve restraint would be warranted if monetary growth did not slow in line with current expectations and there were concurrent indications of intensifying inflationary pressures against the background of stronger economic dat.a
One indication of potential priec pressure might be a further tendency for the dollar to weaken.
The minutes showed that one member, presumably Melzer, preferred a directive that did not contemplate any easing during the weesk ahead.

However, "most of the members did not want ot rule out the possibility of some slight easing during the inter-meeting period, although they did not view the conditions for such a move as likely to emerge."
The FOMC members assumed that ftuure fluctuations in the dollar's value would not be of sufficient magnitude to have any significant effect on the Fed's economic projections.
In addition, they anticipated that cosniderable progress would be made in reducing the federal budget deficit.

Standard and Poor's Corp said that the credit quality of most U.S. cable televiison companies is unlikely to improve in the near term.
S and P said that after two years and many delays and disappointments, the cable television industry has firmly established a net cash generating positino.

However, rather than using their improved position to decrease the leverage of current capital structures, the companies' cash flows are being fully leveraged to finance a wave fo consolidations, S and P said.
Many cable television companies exhibit greater financial risk because of their asset growth aspiraitons and debt-financed consolidation.
That delays a lower riks profile for many of them, Standard and Poor's said.
The acquisition and financial grwoth policies of many company executives heavily influenced the ratings outlook.

Citing aggressive capital structures, acquisitions and cash flow coverages of interest expense of between 1.0 and 1.5 tiems, S and P noted that the companies are more debt intensive now than in their building phase.
These factors keep their ratings at speculative graeds, the agency concluded.

The United States defended its sales of stockpiled tin in 1968 in reaction to criticism from Malaysian miners who have said it violated an agreement with southeast Asian producers.

"The United States has continued to abide by the spirit of the memorandum of understanding and has consulted with the ASEAN sttaes on GSA tin disposals," a State Department spokesman said in a statement.
"The views of the ASEAN governments have been taken into account ni determining disposal levels," the statement said.
The United States and the ASEAN countries signed a memorandum of undertsanding concerning tin disposals by the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) in December 1983.
In its latest annual report, the States of Malaya Chamber of Mines said the GSA sold 5,490 tonnes of tin in 1986, well abvoe an agreed upon annual limit of 3,000 tonnes.
"The United States appears to have lost sight of the U.S./ASEAN Memornadum of Understanding," it said.
The State Department sattement said GSA tin disposals increased in calendar year 1986 due to changed market conditions.
During the first uqarter of calendar year 1987, they have been running at a lower rate compared to 1986.
The sopkesman declined to say how much stockpiled tin the GSA sold last year, however.
